{{Infobox person | name = Jorie Graham | image = Jorie Graham 2007 (2).png | alt = | caption = Jorie Graham, speaking at a poetry reading in 2007 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|05|09}} | birth_place = [[New York City]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = United States | other_names = | occupation = poet | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Jorie Graham''' (born May 9, 1950) is an American poet. The [[Poetry Foundation]] called Graham "one of the most celebrated poets of the American post-war generation."<ref name="poetryfoundation">Poetry Foundation, [http://www.poetryfoundation.org/archive/poet.html?id=2661 Jorie Graham (1950-) Biography] (accessed 8 May 2010)</ref> She replaced poet [[Seamus Heaney]] as Boylston Professor at [[Harvard]], becoming the first woman to be appointed to this position.<ref name="poetryfoundation"/> She won the [[Pulitzer Prize]] for Poetry (1996) for ''The Dream of the Unified Field: Selected Poems 1974-1994'' and was chancellor of the [[Academy of American Poets]] from 1997 to 2003.
==Books and awards== Jorie Graham is the author of numerous collections of poetry, including notable volumes like ''The End of Beauty'', ''The Dream of the Unified Field: Selected Poems 1974-1994'', and ''P L A C E''. She has also edited two anthologies, ''Earth Took of Earth: 100 Great Poems of the English Language'' (1996) and ''The Best American Poetry 1990''. She is widely anthologized and her poetry is the subject of many essays, including ''Jorie Graham: Essays on the Poetry'' (2005). The Poetry Foundation considers Graham's third book, ''The End of Beauty'' (1987), to have been a "watershed" book in which Graham first used the longer verse line for which she is best known.<ref>[http://www.poetryfoundation.org/bio/jorie-graham The Poetry Foundation. "Jorie Graham: Biography." Online]</ref> Graham's many honors include a [[Whiting Awards|Whiting Award]] (1985), the John D. and Catherine T. [[MacArthur Fellowship]], an [[Ingram Merrill Foundation|Ingram Merrill]] Fellowship, The Morton Dauwen Zabel Award from The [[American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters]] and the Whiting Award.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whiting.org/awards/winners/jorie-graham#/|title=whiting awards {{!}} Jorie Graham - 1985 Winner in Poetry|last=|first=|date=|work=whiting.org|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref> ''The Dream of the Unified Field: Selected Poems 1974-1994'' won the 1996 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for Poetry. Her collection of poetry ''P L A C E'' won the 2012 [[Forward Poetry Prize]] for best collection, becoming the first American woman ever to win one of the UK's most prestigious poetry accolades.<ref name=flood2012>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/oct/01/forwardprizeforpoetry-poetry |title=Jorie Graham takes 2012 Forward prize |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Alison Flood |date=1 October 2012 |accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> ''P L A C E'' was also shortlisted for the 2012 [[T S Eliot Prize]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/oct/23/ts-eliot-prize-poetry-shortlist |title=TS Eliot prize for poetry announces 'fresh, bold' shortlist |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Alison Flood |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> In 2013, Graham became only the third American to win the International [[Nonino]] Prize. In 2015, ''From the New World: Selected Poems 1976-2014''—a collection from all prior eleven volumes plus new work—was published by [[HarperCollins]]/[[Ecco Press]]. In 2016 ''From the New World'' won the ''LA Times Book Award'' for poetry''.''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-ca-jc-festival-of-books-winners-20160331-snap-htmlstory.html|title=Here are the 2016 L.A. Times Book Prize winners|last=Lewis|first=David|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
In 2017, Graham received the Wallace Stevens Award from the [[Academy of American Poets]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/academy-american-poets/stanza/academy-american-poets-announces-recipients-2017-american-poets-prizes|title=The Academy of American Poets Announces the Recipients of the 2017 American Poets Prizes|last=nparedes|date=2017-08-15|website=The Academy of American Poets Announces the Recipients of the 2017 American Poets Prizes|language=en|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref> Given annually to recognize outstanding and proven mastery in the art of poetry, recipients are nominated and elected by a majority vote of the Academy's Board of Chancellors. She won the 2018 [[Bobbitt National Prize for Poetry]] for ''Fast''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/01/arts/jorie-graham-bobbitt-poetry-prize.html|title=Jorie Graham Wins Bobbitt Poetry Prize|access-date=2018-11-02|language=en}}</ref>
About Jorie Graham, Academy of American Poets Chancellor [[Claudia Rankine]] said: "Jorie Graham's masterful poems traverse almost four decades of inquiry into what it means to be in relation. Her work pulls forward our mythical, historical, environmental, and personal narratives in order to inhabit our most ordinary and collective experiences. Hers is the patience of the return; repetition in her work unearths the nuances of fundamental desires to live, to love, to be. Clear-eyed and with a scope that encompasses what is both known and unknown, her fifteen collections have built towards a brilliant insistence on presence."<ref name=":0" />
She served as a Chancellor of The [[Academy of American Poets]] from 1997 to 2003, and she currently sits on the contributing editorial board to the literary journal ''[[Conjunctions]]''.
==Life== Jorie Graham was born in [[New York City]] in 1950 to [[Curtis Bill Pepper]], a war correspondent and the head of the Rome bureau for ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine, and the sculptor [[Beverly Pepper|Beverly Stoll Pepper]]. She was raised in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. She studied philosophy at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]], but was expelled for participating in student protests. She completed her undergraduate work as a film major at [[New York University]], and became interested in poetry during that time. (She claims that her interest was sparked while walking past M.L. Rosenthal's classroom and overhearing the last couplet of "[[The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock]]" ). After working as a secretary, she later went on to receive her Master of Fine Arts from the famed [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]] at the [[University of Iowa]].
Graham has held a longtime faculty position at the Iowa Writers' Workshop, and has held an appointment at [[Harvard University]] since 1999. Graham replaced [[Nobel Laureate]] and poet [[Seamus Heaney]] as Boylston professor in Harvard's Department of English and American Literature and Language. She became the first woman to be awarded this position.<ref name="poetryfoundation" /><ref name="orr">David Orr, "ON POETRY; Jorie Graham, Superstar," 'New York Times ''Sunday Book Review,'' April 24, 2005; [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/24/books/review/24ORRL.html available] at the Time website (accessed March 16, 2008)</ref>
Graham was married to and divorced from publishing heir William Graham, brother of [[Donald E. Graham]], now publisher of ''[[The Washington Post]]''. She then married the poet [[James Galvin (poet)|James Galvin]] in 1983 and they divorced in 1999. She married poet and painter [[Peter M. Sacks]], a colleague at Harvard, in 2000.<ref name="LAtimes">Tomas Alex Tizon, "In Search of Poetic Justice," ''Los Angeles Times'', June 17, 2005. Available at the [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-foetry17jun17,0,4322348,full.story LA Times] (subscription needed). Text is available at [http://www.newpoetryreview.org/forum/viewtopic.php?p=346&sid=7579d596987e6e68e16f022fd314ce22 New Poetry Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725143644/http://www.newpoetryreview.org/forum/viewtopic.php?p=346&sid=7579d596987e6e68e16f022fd314ce22 |date=2012-07-25 }} or [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/07/10/BAGGJDJQJI1.DTL&type=printable SFgate] (accessed 16 March 2007)</ref>
==Poetry competition controversy== In January 1999, she judged the [[University of Georgia]] Contemporary Poetry series contest, which selected the manuscript "O Wheel" from Peter Sacks, her future husband, as the first-place winner. Graham noted that at that time she was not married to Sacks, and that while she had "felt awkward" about giving the award to her then-boyfriend, she had first cleared it with the series editor, Bin Ramke.<ref name="LAtimes"/><ref>Kevin Larimer, "The Contester: Who's Doing What to Keep Them Clean", ''Poets & Writers Magazine,'' July/August 2005. Formerly available at [http://www.pw.org/mag/0511/newslarimer.htm Poets and Writers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071119002839/http://www.pw.org/mag/0511/newslarimer.htm |date=2007-11-19 }} (page currently offline)</ref> As a result of the critical media coverage<ref name="Foetry-Georgia">[http://foetry.com/wp/?page_id=80 Foetry.com archive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613173925/http://foetry.com/wp/?page_id=80 |date=2007-06-13 }}</ref><ref name="chronicle">Thomas Bartlett, "Rhyme and Unreason," ''Chronicle of Higher Education,'' May 20, 2005, [http://chronicle.com/free/v51/i37/37a01201.htm available here] (accessed March 16, 2005)</ref><ref name="guardian">John Sutherland, "American foetry," ''The Guardian'', Monday July 4, 2005 [http://books.guardian.co.uk/news/articles/0,6109,1520718,00.html the Guardian]</ref> Ramke resigned from the editorship of the series. Graham subsequently announced that she would no longer serve as a judge in contests<ref name="LAtimes"/><ref name="chronicle"/> although she continued to do so after 2008.<ref>Graham was selected to judge the 2008 [http://www.92y.org/content/literary_programs.asp#3 "Discovery"/Boston Review 2008 Poetry Contest], with deadline January 18, 2008; and judged the Baker Nord Poetry Competition [https://jacoboet.com/poetry/ in 2011].</ref> Throughout the course of the contest, Ramke had insisted that judges of the contest be kept secret, and until Foetry.com obtained the names of judges via The Open Records Act, the conflict of interest had been undisclosed. A statement now adopted in the rules of many competitions (including the University of Georgia Contest) to prevent judges from selecting students is often referred to as the "Jorie Graham rule".<ref name="guardian"/><ref name="globe">Alex Beam, "Website polices rhymes and misdemeanors," ''Boston Globe'', March 31, 2005, [http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2005/03/31/website_polices_rhymes_and_misdemeanors/ available here]</ref><ref name="Foetry-graham">[http://foetry.com/wp/?page_id=85 Foetry page on Jorie Graham]</ref>
The Foetry site also contended that Graham, as a judge at Georgia and other contests, had awarded prizes to at least five of her former students from the Iowa Writers' Workshop, including [[Joshua Clover]], [[Mark Levine (poet)|Mark Levine]], and [[Geoffrey Nutter]].<ref name="Foetry-graham"/> Graham's reply to this was that over years of teaching she has had over 1400 students, many of whom went on to continue writing poetry, that no rules had prohibited her from awarding prizes to former students, and that in each case she claims to have selected the strongest work.<ref name="LAtimes"/>

===Edited anthologies=== * {{cite book| title=The Best American Poetry 1990| editors=Jorie Graham, David Lehman| publisher=Collier Books| year= 1990| isbn= 978-0-02-032785-1 }} * {{cite book| title=Earth Took of Earth: 100 Great Poems of the English Language| publisher=Ecco Press| year= 1996| isbn= 978-0-88001-432-8 }}
===Selected scholarship=== * Helen Vendler. ''The Breaking of Style: Hopkins, Heaney, Graham'' (1995) * Thomas Gardner, ''Regions of Unlikeness: Explaining Contemporary Poetry'' (1999) * Daniel McGuiness, "Jorie Graham in Stitches" and "The Long Line in Jorie Graham and Charles Wright," in ''[http://www.sunypress.edu/p-3349-holding-patterns.aspx Holding Patterns: Temporary Poetics in Contemporary Poetry,]'' State University of New York Press, Albany NY (2001) * Catherine Karaguezian, ''No Image There and the Gaze Remains: The Visual in the Work of Jorie Graham'' (2005) * Thomas Gardner (ed.), ''Jorie Graham: Essays on the Poetry'' (2005)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.joriegraham.com}} * [http://www.poetryfoundation.org/bio/jorie-graham Profile and poems at Poetry Foundation] * [http://www.poets.org/poet.php/prmPID/58 Profile and poems written and audio at Poets.org] * [http://www.whiting.org/awards/winners/jorie-graham#/ Profile at The Whiting Awards] * {{cite journal| url=http://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/263/the-art-of-poetry-no-85-jorie-graham| title=Jorie Graham, The Art of Poetry No. 85| work=The Paris Review| date=Spring 2003| author= Thomas Gardner }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110711014619/http://foetry.com/foetry/mailfraud.pdf Documents obtained by Foetry.com regarding the Graham/Sacks/Ramke collusion in pdf format] * [http://podcast.lannan.org/2010/06/12/jorie-graham-reading-20-may-1999-video/ Graham reading at the Lensic Theater in Santa Fe, New Mexico on May 20, 1999.] Video (49 mins) * [http://chronicle.com/free/v51/i37/37a01201.htm "Rhyme & Unreason" from the May 20, 2005 cover story in the Chronicle of Higher Education] * [http://www.phillyburbs.com/pb-dyn/news/351-04012008-1512367.html An interview with Jorie Graham], phillyBurbs.com, April 2008 * [https://www.thenation.com/article/modernist-poetry-in-a-crowdsourcing-age/ Jorie Graham Resists Classic Pleasures Like Closure, a Concept Anathema to the Poet and Her Country]

page.title: Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development

revision.comment: Fix [[:Category:Pages using deprecated image syntax]]; [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox university |name = Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development |image = kiswcd logo.png |motto = ''Empowering the community for sustainable development'' |established = 1997 |type = [[Private Institute|Private]] |director = [[Benjamin M. Mutie]] |city = [[Nairobi]] |province = [[Nairobi Province]] |country = [[Kenya]] |enrollment = 1300{{cite web|url=http://www.kiswcd.co.ke/ |title=Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development Facts 2008: Enrollments 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-09 |publisher=KISWCD}} |faculty = 40{{cite web|url=http://www.kiswcd.co.ke/faq.html |title=Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community DevelopmentFacts 2008: Faculty and Staff |publisher=MIT |accessdate=2008-09-09}} |campus = Urban, {{convert|25|acre|km2|1}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.kiswcd.co.ke/faq.html |title=MIT Facts 2008: The Campus |publisher=MIT |accessdate=2008-09-09}} |mascot = Book{{cite web|title=Symbols: Book |work=KISWCD Graphic Identity |publisher=MIT |url=http://www.kiswcd.co.ke/Picha/BG_YA_MADA.gif |accessdate=2008-09-09 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} |website = [http://www.kiswcd.co.ke www.kiswcd.co.ke] |coor = {{Coord|-1.287013|36.837603|type:edu|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |colors = Blue and white{{Ref_label|a|a|none}}
{{Color box|#00CCFF}}{{Color box|#FFFFFF}} |affiliations = [[Kenya National Examination Council|KNEC]], [[Association of Business Managers and Administrators|ABMA UK]], [[Assessment and Qualification Alliance|AQA UK]], [[Association of Business Executives|ABE]], [[Institute of Management of Information Systems|IMIS]], [[London Centre of Marketing|LCM]], [[Kenya Accountancy and Secretarial Board|KASNEB]], [[Institute of Commercial Management|ICM]], [[Microsoft certified system engineer|MCSE]], [[International Computer Certifications|ICC]], [[Microsoft Certified Application Development|MCAD]]}} {{Portal|University}} The '''Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development''' ('''KISWCD''') is a community-focused development and training institution without any governmental, religious or political affiliation. KISWCD was initiated in 1997 and incorporated on 22 June 2000 as a private company limited by guarantee. It was registered by the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology on 22 August 2002 as a training institution. The institute is managed by a Board of Governors who are experienced in the areas of social work, educational institutions management, business management, human resources management, finance and accounting, psychology, environmental health, counselling and law. KISWCD is an examination centre for [[Kenya National Examination Council|KNEC]], [[Institute of Commercial Management|ICM]] UK, [[Assessment and Qualifications Alliance|AQA]] UK, and [[Association of Business Managers and Administrators|ABMA]] among others. The institution offers [[Academic certificate|certificate]] and diploma courses in [[Community Development]], [[Social Work]] and Welfare, [[Project Management]], [[Community Health]] and [[Counseling]]. Short courses and consultancy services are available. Students from Uganda, Tanzania, Mozambique, Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia are among those who have enrolled in KISWCD. The main campus is located at NACICO Plaza, 6th Floor, on Landhies Road, Nairobi. ==Academics== ===Intake=== KISWCD has intakes in January and June every year. Registration for the distance learning programme is possible throughout the year. Students can register online. ===Mode of study=== * Full-time (daytime)- 8.00 am - 6.00 pm, Mon - Fri * Evening classes - 5.30 pm - 7.30 pm, Mon - Fri * Saturday classes - 8.00 am - 4.00 pm * Blocks - April, August, and December * Distant Learning Programme (learning by correspondence) ===Examinations=== Examinations are administered by several examination bodies namely: * [[Kenya National Examination Council]] (KNEC) * Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development ([[KISWCD]]) * [[Association of Business Managers and Administrators]] (ABMA UK) * [[Assessment and Qualification Alliance]] ([[Assessment and Qualifications Alliance|AQA]] UK) The programmes evaluation and quality assurance is done by the [[Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (Kenya)|Ministry of Education, Science and Technology]], [[Commission for Higher Education]], [[Kenya Methodist University]] and individual institutions that collaborating with KISWCD. ===Field work attachment=== All students are required to get attachments in NGOs, churches and other organisations involved in community work for not less than three months. This takes place during the academic year and is a mandatory requirement. ===Extracurricular=== The institute sponsors an annual sports day where students and teachers play against each other. ===Short courses=== Short courses are organised at the beginning of each year. The institute links up with [[Kenya Institute of Social Work]] to offer training. ==Accommodation== KISWCD does not offer in-house accommodation for students. However, arrangements are made to secure safe accommodation, with the cost met by the students. ==Consultancy== The objective of the consultancy services is to provide advice in particular areas of expertise. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * Kenya Institute of Social Work and Community Development [http://www.kiswcd.co.ke/ KISWCD website] * Kenya Ministry of Education [http://www.education.go.ke/ Ministry of Education website] * Kenya National Examination Council [http://www.examscouncil.or.ke/ Examination Council website] [[Category:Technical universities and colleges]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Kenya]] [[Category:Education in Kenya]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1997]] [[Category:1997 establishments in Kenya]]

page.title: List of higher education associations and alliances

revision.text:
Many institutions of higher education often combine their resources so that they can share information and resources, coordinate research agendas, and afford each other mutual support.
==Legal== *[[Association of American Law Schools]] *[[Law Schools Global League]]
==Medical== *[[Association of American Medical Colleges]] * [[MedCity (London)|MedCity]] – collaboration between medical research universities in London
==Research-based associations== * [[Association of American Universities]] - Group of leading American and Canadian research universities * [[Europaeum]] * [[League of European Research Universities]] * [[Universities Research Association]] – A corporation for management of research facilities formed by a consortium of universities, primarily in the [[United States]] but also internationally * [[Russell Group]] – A group of research-based universities in the [[United Kingdom]] * [[Group of Eight (Australian universities)]] - A group of leading Australian tertiary institutions intensive in research and comprehensive in general and professional education *[[U15 Group of Canadian Research Universities]] - A group of 15 Canadian public research universities * [[International Alliance of Research Universities]] * [[International Research Universities Network]] * [[IDEA League]] (a strategic alliance of five of Europe's leading technical research universities) * [[C9 League]] (China) * [[U15 (German Universities)|U15]] (Germany) * [[TU9]] (Germany) * [[Eastern ARC]] (research consortium in eastern England) * [[M5 (universities)|M5]] (research consortium in the English Midlands) * [[GW4]] (research consortium in southwest England and Wales) * [[N8 Research Partnership]] (research consortium in northern England) * [[SES (universities)|SES]] (research consortium in southeast England) * [[White Rose University Consortium]] (research consortium in Yorkshire) * [[G5 (universities)|G5]] (group of research universities in southeast England) * [[Matariki Network of Universities]] – international group of research universities * [[PLuS Alliance]]
==Geographic==
===Arctic region===
* [[University of the Arctic]]
===Africa=== * [[Association of African Universities]]
===Canada=== * [[Association of Canadian Community Colleges]] * [[Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada]]
===Colombia=== * [[Colombia - Challenge Your Knowledge -CCYK-]]
===Europe=== * [[Coimbra Group]] * Conferenza dei Collegi Universitari di Merito * [[Couperin (consortium)|Couperin]] (Consortium unifié des établissements universitaires et de recherche pour l'accès aux publications numériques), France * European University Alliance * [[EAIE]] * [[Eucor]] * [[EURODOC]] * [[Europaeum]] * [[IDEA League]] * [[Institutional Network of the Universities from the Capitals of Europe]] * [[League of European Research Universities]] * The Guild of European Research-Intensive Universities * [[Utrecht Network]] * [[Young European Research Universities Network]] * [[European Consortium of Innovative Universities]]
=== India ===
* [[Institution of National Importance|Institutions of National Importance]] * [[Indian Institutes of Technology]] * [[National Institutes of Technology]]
===Mexico=== * [[AMPEI]] (AMPEI)
===Pacific Rim=== * [[Association of Pacific Rim Universities]]
===United Kingdom=== * [[Universities UK]] * [[University Alliance]] * [[Million+]] * [[GuildHE]] * [[Wallace Group]] * [[SETsquared]]
===United States=== * [[Association of American Colleges and Universities]] * [[Oak Ridge Associated Universities]] * [[Great Cities' Universities]] * [[Association of Independent Technological Universities]]
==Geographically Non-Specific== *[[Association of Commonwealth Universities]] *[[Worldwide Universities Network]] * [[Academic Cooperation Association]] (ACA) * [[International Association of Universities]] (IAU) *[[Universitas 21]]
==Language-based== * [[Agence universitaire de la Francophonie]] - French
==Religious==
* [[Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities]] – An organization made up of [[Jesuit]] institutions of higher education in the [[United States]] * [[Cathedrals Group]] – association of British universities and university colleges with Christian foundations
[[Category:Higher education|*]] [[Category:Higher education-related lists|Associations and alliances]]

{{Commonscat|Music museums}}{{TOC right}} This is a '''list of music museums''' worldwide. The list contains notable former and existing museums that focus on musicians, musical instruments or other musical subjects.
== Argentina == * {{ill|Museo de las Campanas|es}} – [[Mina Clavero]] * [[Academia Nacional del Tango de la República Argentina]] – [[Buenos Aires]] * {{ill|Museo de instrumentos musicales Emilio Azzarini|es}} – [[La Plata]] * {{ill|Museo Beatle|nl}}, dedicated to [[The Beatles]] – Buenos Aires
== Armenia == * [[House-Museum of Aram Khachaturian]], dedicated to [[Aram Khachaturian]] – Jerevan * [[Charles Aznavour Museum]], dedicated to [[Charles Aznavour]] – [[Yerevan]]
== Australia == * [[National Film and Sound Archive]] – [[Acton, Australian Capital Territory|Acton]], [[Australian Capital Territory]] * [[Tandanya National Aboriginal Cultural Institute]] – [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] * [[National Library of Australia]] – [[Canberra]], [[Australian Capital Territory]] * Australian Country Music Hall of Fame – Tamworth, [[New South Wales]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com.au/default.htm|title=DEFAULT|website=www.countrymusichalloffame.com.au|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> * [[Grainger Museum]], dedicated to [[Percy Grainger]] – [[University of Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] * [[Performing Arts Collection]] – [[Melbourne]] * [[Arts Centre Melbourne]], musical collection – Melbourne * [[ARIA Hall of Fame]] – Melbourne * [[Australian Jazz Museum]] – Wantirna, Victoria
== Austria == [[File:WienPasqualatihaus.jpg|thumb|Pasqualati-Haus]] ; Dedicated to composers dedicated to [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] * {{ill|Beethoven-Haus Krems|nl|Beethoven-Haus (Krems an der Donau)}} – [[Krems an der Donau]] * {{ill|Beethoven-Haus Baden|de|Beethovenhaus Baden}} – [[Baden bei Wien]], [[Vienna]] * {{ill|Erdődy estate|de|Erdődy-Landgut}} (1973–2013) – [[Floridsdorf]], Vienna * {{ill|Bezirksmuseum Floridsdorf|de|Bezirksmuseum Floridsdorf}}, musical collection – Floridsdorf * {{ill|Eroica-Haus|nl|Bieder-Hof}} – Vienna * {{ill|Haus des Heiligenstädter Testaments|de}} – Vienna * {{ill|Pasqualati-Haus|de}} – Vienna
dedicated to [[Anton Bruckner]] * {{ill|Anton-Bruckner-Museum|nl}} – [[Ansfelden]] * {{ill|Kronstorfer Brucknerzimmer|nl}} – [[Kronstorf]]
dedicated to [[Johannes Brahms]] and/or [[Joseph Haydn]] * {{ill|Brahmsmuseum Mürzzuschlag|de|Brahmsmuseum Mürzzuschlag}} – [[Mürzzuschlag]] * {{ill|Haydn-Haus Vienna|nl|Haydn-Haus (Wenen)}} with Brahms room – [[Vienna]] * {{ill|Haydn-Haus Eisenstadt|de|Haydn-Haus Eisenstadt}} – [[Eisenstadt]] * [[Bergkirche (Eisenstadt)|Haydnkirche]] – Eisenstadt * [[Haydn's birthplace]], dedicated to Joseph and [[Michael Haydn]] – [[Rohrau, Austria|Rohrau]]
dedicated to [[Gustav Mahler]] * [[Composing hut of Gustav Mahler (Attersee)|Composing hut of Gustav Mahler]] – [[Steinbach am Attersee]] * [[Composing hut of Gustav Mahler (Wörthersee)|Composing hut of Gustav Mahler]] – Maiernigg near [[Maria Wörth]]
dedicated to [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] and/or family members * {{ill|Mozarthaus,|de|Mozarthaus St. Gilgen}} dedicated to [[Maria Anna Mozart|Nannerl Mozart]] and her mother – [[St. Gilgen]] * [[Mozart's birthplace]] – [[Salzburg]] * {{ill|Mozarts Wohnhaus|nl}}, dedicated to the whole family – Salzburg * [[Mozarthaus Vienna|Mozarthaus]] – [[Vienna]]
dedicated to [[Franz Schubert]] * {{ill|Schloss Atzenbrugg|de}} – [[Atzenbrugg]] * {{ill|Birth house of Franz Schubert|nl|Geboortehuis van Franz Schubert}} – [[Vienna]] * {{ill|Death house of Franz Schubert|nl|Overlijdenshuis van Franz Schubert}} – Vienna
dedicated to the Strauss family * [[Museum der Johann Strauss Dynastie]], dedicated to the family Strauss – [[Vienna]] * {{ill|Johann Strauss Wohnung|nl}}, dedicated to [[Johann Strauss II]] – Vienna
dedicated to [[Arnold Schoenberg]] * {{ill|Schönberg-Haus|de}} – [[Mödling]] * [[Arnold Schönberg Center]] – Vienna
dedicated to other composers * {{ill|Zeitbrücke-Museum|de}}, partly dedicated to [[Franz von Suppé]] – [[Gars am Kamp]] * {{ill|Lehár-Villa|de}}, dedicated to [[Franz Lehár]] – [[Bad Ischl]] * {{ill|Carl Zeller-Museum|nl}}, dedicated to [[Carl Zeller]] – [[Sankt Peter in der Au|St. Peter in der Au]] * [[Liszthaus Raiding|Liszthaus]], dedicated to [[Franz Liszt]] – [[Raiding, Austria|Raiding]]
; [[Vienna]] (other museums) * {{ill|Fatty-George-Jazzmus|nl}}, dedicated to [[Fatty George]] * [[Haus der Musik]] * [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]], musical collection * [[Vienna Technical Museum]], musical collection
; Other museums * [[Eboardmuseum]] – [[Klagenfurt]] * {{ill|Musikinstrumentenmuseum Schloss Kremsegg|nl}} – [[Kremsmünster]] * {{ill|Stille-Nacht & Heimatmuseum|de|Stille Nacht Museum Oberndorf}}, partly dedicated to ''[[Silent Night]]'' – [[Oberndorf bei Salzburg]] * {{ill|Blasmusikmuseum|nl}} – [[Ratten]]

[[Antwerp (province)|Province of Antwerp]] * [[Vleeshuis|Museum Vleeshuis]] – [[Antwerp]] * [[Harmonium Art museuM]] – [[Willebroek|Klein-Willebroek]] * [[Royal Carillon School "Jef Denyn"]], dedicated to [[Jef Denyn]] – [[Mechelen]] * {{ill|Barrel Organ Museum Voortkapel|nl|Draaiorgelmuseum (Voortkapel)}} – Voortkapel, [[Westerlo]]
[[Brussels]] and [[Flemish Brabant]] * {{ill|Archive and Museum for Flemish Way of Living|nl|Archief en Museum voor het Vlaams Leven te Brussel}}, musical collection – [[City of Brussels|Brussels]] * [[Musical Instrument Museum (Brussels)|Musical Instrument Museum]] – Brussels * {{ill|Popular Instruments Museum Gooik|nl|Volksinstrumentenmuseum}} – [[Gooik]] * [[South-West Brabant Museum]], collection of cellist [[Adrien-François Servais|François Servais]] and family – [[Halle, Belgium|Halle]] * [[Jazz Station]] – [[Saint-Josse-ten-Noode]] * [[Brabant Center for Music Traditions]] – [[Kampenhout]] * {{ill|Museum van de Radio- en Televisie-Omroep|nl}} (1979–1996) – [[Schaerbeek]]
[[Limburg (Belgium)|Limburg]] * {{ill|Stedelijk Beiaardmuseum|nl}} – [[Hasselt]] * {{ill|Museum for Musical Instruments Peer|nl|Museum voor muziekinstrumenten (Peer)}} (?–2014) – [[Peer, Belgium|Peer]] * [[Armand Preud'homme Museum]] (1990–2018), dedicated to [[Armand Preud'homme]] – Peer
[[Wallonia]] * [[Mr Sax's House]], dedicated to [[Adolphe Sax]] – [[Dinant]] * [[Bell and Carillon Museum]] (1992–2013) – [[Tellin]]
== Brazil == * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som de Bauru|pt}} – [[Bauru]] * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som de Campinas|pt}} – [[Campinas]] * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som de Campo Grande|pt|Museu da Imagem e do Som (Campo Grande)}} – [[Campo Grande]] * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som do Ceará|pt}} – [[Ceará]] * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som de Cuiabá|pt}} – [[Cuiabá]] *[[Museu da Imagem e do Som de Alagoas]] – [[Maceió]] * {{ill|Museu da Música de Mariana|pt}} – [[Minas Gerais]] * {{ill|Museu da Imagem e do Som do Pará|pt}} – [[Pará]] * {{ill|Luiz Gonzaga Museum|pt|Museu de Luiz Gonzaga}}, dedicated to [[Luiz Gonzaga]] – [[Pernambuco]] * [[Museu da Imagem e do Som do Rio de Janeiro]] – [[Rio de Janeiro]] * Villa-Lobos Museum, dedicated to [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]] – [[Rio de Janeiro]]<ref name="Universidade Lusófona">Universidade Lusófona de Humanidades e Tecnologias, Departamento de Museologia, [http://www.museologia-portugal.net/files/upload/doutoramentos/tania_mendonca.pdf Museos da imagem e dos Som], 2012</ref> * [[São Paulo Museum of Image and Sound]] – [[São Paulo]]
== Burkina Faso == * [[Musée de Manega]], musical collection – [[Oubritenga Province|Oubritenga]] * [[National Museum of Music (Burkina Faso)|National Musical Museum]] – [[Ouagadougou]]
== Canada == [[British Columbia]], [[Alberta]] and [[Saskatchewan]] * Gervais Wheels Museum – Alida, Saskatchewan<ref>Alan Samuel, Treasures Of Canada, 1998, [https://books.google.nl/books?id=TYLm0bu4piIC&pg=PA294&lpg=PA294&dq=%22Gervais+Wheels+Museum%22+Alida&source=bl&ots=cUfu0tOjwN&sig=IMYfovSIWqin70tlthaXKKJaKVc&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjolZC264LeAhXS_aQKHZsnBy0Q6AEwBXoECAsQAQ#v=onepage page294]</ref> * [[National Music Centre]] – [[Calgary]] * [[Creative Kids Museum]], musical collection – Calgary * [[Canadian Music Hall of Fame]] – Calgary * [[Canadian Songwriters Hall of Fame]] – Calgary * [[Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame]] – [[Merritt, British Columbia|Merritt]] * Revelstoke Nickelodeon Museum – [[Revelstoke, British Columbia|Revelstoke]]<ref>Radiomuseum, [https://www.radiomuseum.org/museum/cdn/nickelodeon-museum-revelstoke/.html Revelstoke Nickelodeon Museum]</ref>

revision.comment: /* top */ and /* History */ +inlink [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]]
revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=February 2012}} A '''math circle''' is a social structure where participants engage in the depths and intricacies of mathematical thinking, propagate the culture of doing mathematics, and create knowledge. To reach these goals, participants partake in problem-solving, mathematical modeling, the practice of art, and philosophical discourse. Some circles involve competition, others do not; all promote camaraderie.<ref name=Mark2006>{{cite web|last=Saul|first=Mark|title=What is a Math Circle|url=http://www.mathcircles.org/what-is-a-math-circle/|work=National Association of Math Circles Wiki|publisher=[[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]]|accessdate=31 January 2018|year=2006}}</ref>
==Characteristics==
Math circles can have a variety of styles. Some are very informal, with the learning proceeding through games, stories, or hands-on activities. Others are more traditional enrichment classes, but without formal examinations. Some have a strong emphasis on preparing for [[Math Olympiads|olympiad competitions]]; some avoid competition as much as possible. Models can use any combination of these techniques, depending on the audience, the mathematician, and the environment of the circle. Athletes have sports teams through which to deepen their involvement with sports; math circles can play a similar role for kids who like to think. Two features all math circles have in common are (1) that they are composed of students who want to be there - they either like math, or want to like math, and (2) that they give students a social context in which to enjoy mathematics.<ref name=Mark2006/>
==History== Mathematical enrichment activities in the United States have been around since sometime before 1977, in the form of residential summer programs, math contests, and local school-based programs.<ref name=Vandervelde2007/> The concept of a math circle, on the other hand, with its emphasis on convening professional mathematicians and secondary school students on a regular basis to solve problems, appeared in the U.S. sometime between 1995 and 2001.<ref name=Vandervelde2007/> This form of mathematical outreach made its way to the U.S. most directly from Russia and Bulgaria.<ref name=Vandervelde2007/> They first appeared in Russia during the 1930s; they have existed in Bulgaria since sometime before 1907.<ref name=Vandervelde2007/> The tradition arrived in the U.S. with émigrés who had received their inspiration from math circles as teenagers.<ref name=Vandervelde2007/> Many of them successfully climbed the academic ladder to secure positions within universities, and a few pioneers among them decided to initiate math circles within their communities to preserve the tradition which had been so pivotal in their own formation as mathematicians.<ref name=Vandervelde2007>{{cite book|last=Vandervelde|first=Sam|title=Circle in a Box|url=http://www.mathcircles.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/circleinabox.pdf|publisher=[[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]]|year=2007}}</ref> These days, math circles frequently partner with other mathematical education organizations, such at the [[Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival]]<ref>[https://www.maa.org/press/periodicals/maa-focus/capital-math-a-julia-robinson-mathematics-festival-comes-to-dc Capital Math: A Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival Comes to D.C.] Mathematical Association of America Press: June/July 2012 issue of MAA FOCUS</ref> and the [[Mandelbrot Competition]].<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/ithacahighmathteam/about-us/awards-achievements-and-college Ithaca Math Circle wins 2nd place 2011 Mandelbrot Competition] Awards and Achievements: Ithaca Math Circle</ref>
==Content choices== Decisions about content are difficult for newly forming math circles and clubs, or for parents seeking groups for their children.
'''Project-based clubs''' may spend a few meetings building origami, developing a math trail in their town, or programming a mathy computer game together. Math-rich projects may be artistic, exploratory, applied to sciences, executable (software-based), business-oriented, or directed at real contributions to local communities. Museums, cultural and business clubs, tech groups, online networks, artists/musicians/actors active in the community, and other individual professionals can make math projects especially real and meaningful. Increasingly, math clubs invite remote participation of active people (authors, community leaders, professionals) through webinar and teleconferencing software.
'''Problem-solving circles''' get together to pose and solve interesting, deep, meaningful math problems. Problems considered "good" are easy to pose, challenging to solve, require connections among several concepts and techniques, and lead to significant math ideas. Best problem solving practices include meta-cognition (managing memory and attention), grouping problems by type and conceptual connections (e.g. "river crossing problems"), moving between more general and abstract problems and particular, simpler examples, and collaboration with other club members, with current online communities, and with past mathematicians through the media they contributed to the culture.
'''Guided exploration circles''' use self-discovery and the Socratic method to probe deep questions. Robert & Ellen Kaplan, in their book Out of the Labyrinth: Setting Mathematics Free,<ref>Kaplan, Robert, and Ellen Kaplan. Out of the Labyrinth: Setting Mathematics Free. Oxford; New York: Oxford University Press, 2007.</ref> make a case for this format describing the non-profit Cambridge/Boston Math Circle they founded in 1994 in the Harvard University. The book describes the classroom, organizational and practical issues the Kaplans faced in founding their Math Circle. The meetings encourage a free discussion of ideas; while the content is mathematically rigorous, the atmosphere is friendly and relaxed. The philosophy of the teachers is, "''What you have been obliged to discover by yourself leaves a path in your mind which you can use again when the need arises''" ([[G. C. Lichtenberg]]). Children are encouraged to ask exploratory questions. Are there numbers between numbers? What's a geometry like with no parallel lines? Can you tile a square with squares all of different sizes?
'''Research mathematicians''' and connecting students with them can be a focus of math circles. Students in these circles appreciate and start to attain the very special way of thinking in research mathematics, such as generalizing problems, continue asking deeper questions, seeing similarities across different examples and so on.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://math.asu.edu/~mathcircle/ |title=Math Circle at ASU Tempe}}</ref>
'''Topic-centered clubs''' follow math themes, such as clock arithmetic, fractals, or linearity. Club members write and read essays, pose and solve problems, create and study definitions, build interesting example spaces, and investigate applications of their current topic. There are lists of time-tested, classic math club topics, especially rich in connections and accessible to a wide range of abilities. The plus of using a classic topic is the variety of resources available from the past; however, bringing a relatively obscure or new topic to the attention of the club and the global community is very rewarding, as well.
'''Applied math clubs''' center on a field other than mathematics, such as math for thespians, computer programming math, or musical math. Such clubs need strong leadership both for the math parts and for the other field part. Such clubs can meet at an artists' studio, at a game design company, at a theater or another authentic professional setting. More examples of fruitful applied math pathways include history, storytelling, art, inventing and tinkering, toy and game design, robotics, origami, and natural sciences.
Most circles and clubs mix some features of the above types. For example, the Metroplex Math Circle <ref>{{cite web|url=http://metroplexmathcircle.wordpress.com/ |title=Metroplex Math Circle}}</ref> has a combination of problem-solving and research, and the New York Math Circle <ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymathcircle.org/ |title=New York Math Circle}}</ref> is some combination of a problem-solving circle and a topic-centered club, with vestiges of a research circle.
One can expect problem-solving groups to attract kids already strong in math and confident in their math abilities. On the other hand, math anxious kids will be more likely to try project-based or applied clubs. Topic-centered clubs typically work with kids who can all work at about the same level. The decision about the type of the club strongly depends on your target audience.
==Competition decisions== Math competitions involve comparing speed, depth, or accuracy of math work among several people or groups. Traditionally, European competitions are more depth-oriented, and Asian and North American competitions are more speed-oriented, especially for younger children. The vast majority of math competitions involve solving closed-ended (known answers) problems, however, there are also essay, project and software competitions. As with all tests requiring limited time, the problems focus more on the empirical accuracy and foundations of mathematics work rather than an extension of basic knowledge. More often than not, competition differs entirely from curricular mathematics in requiring creativity in elementary applications—so that although there may be closed answers, it takes significant extension of mathematical creativity in order to successfully achieve the ends.
For some people,{{Who|date=September 2011}} competition carries with it a negative connotation and corollary of greed for victory rather than an appreciation of mathematics. However, those who run math circles centering mostly on competition rather than seminars and lessons attest that this is a large assumption. Rather, participants grow in their appreciation of math via math competitions such as the [[American Mathematics Competitions|AMC]], [[American Invitational Mathematics Examination|AIME]], [[United States of America Mathematical Olympiad|USAMO]], and [[American Regions Mathematics League|ARML]].
Some math circles are completely devoted to preparing teams or individuals for particular competitions. The biggest plus of the competition framework for a circle organizer is the ready-made set of well-defined goals. The competition provides a time and task management structure, and easily defined progress tracking. This is also the biggest minus of competition-based mathematics, because defining goals and dealing with complexity and chaos are important in all real-world endeavors. Competitive math circles attract students who are already strong and confident in mathematics, but also welcome those who wish to engage in the mathematics competitive world. Beyond the age of ten or so, they also attract significantly more males than females, and in some countries, their racial composition is disproportionate to the country's demographic.
Collaborative math clubs are more suitable for kids who are anxious about mathematics, need "math therapy" because of painful past experiences, or want to have more casual and artistic relationships with mathematics. A playgroup or a coop that does several activities together, including a math club, usually chooses collaborative or hybrid models that are more likely to accommodate all members already in the group.
Most math circles and clubs combine some competitive and some collaborative activities. For example, many math circles, while largely centering on competitions, host seasonal tournaments and infuse their competition seminars with fun mathematical lessons.
==References== <references group="MSRI Circle in a Box"/> {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Mathilde Marchesi | image = Matilde Marchesi.jpg | alt = | caption = Mathilde Marchesi | birth_name = Mathilde Graumann | birth_date = {{Birth date|1821|3|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Frankfurt]], Germany | death_date = {{Death date and age|1913|11|17|1821|3|24|df=y}} | death_place = London, United Kingdom | nationality = German | other_names = | spouse = {{Marriage|Salvatore Marchesi|1852}} | occupation = [[mezzo-soprano]]
Teacher of singing | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | signature = MathildeMarchesisignature.png }} [[File:MathildeMarchesi1897.png|thumb|Mathilde Marchesi, from an 1897 publication.]] '''Mathilde Marchesi''' (24 March 1821 – 17 November 1913) was a German [[mezzo-soprano]], a renowned teacher of singing, and a proponent of the [[bel canto]] vocal method. ==Biography== Marchesi was born in [[Frankfurt]]. Her father's name was Graumann; her aunt was the pianist and friend of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], [[Dorothea von Ertmann]], née Graumann. In her adolescence her family fortunes failed, so she travelled at the age of 22 to Vienna to study voice. Thereafter she went to Paris and studied with [[Manuel García (baritone)|Manuel García II]], who was to have the foremost influence on her. She made her debut as a singer in 1844, and had a short career in [[opera]] and recital. Her voice, however, was only adequate, so she moved to teaching in 1849. In 1852, she married Italian baritone Salvatore Marchesi, Cavaliere de Castrone (d. 1908). It was in this field that she would become famous. She taught at conservatories in Cologne and Vienna and in 1881 opened her own school on the {{ill|Rue Jouffroy-d'Abbans|fr}} in Paris, where she was to remain for most of her life. Ultimately, she was best known as the vocal teacher of a number of great singers. The most famous among them is perhaps [[Nellie Melba]], but she also trained such illustrious singers as [[Emma Calvé]], [[Frances Alda]], [[Ellen Gulbranson]], [[Selma Kurz]] and [[Emma Eames]]. Marchesi died in London in 1913. The mother of [[Joan Sutherland]] was taught by a pupil of Marchesi. Today, Marchesi is remembered not at all for her singing career. Rather, she is known first and foremost as the teacher of a surprising number of great singers, and also as the person who carried the bel canto technique into the 20th century. Her ideas are still studied, primarily by female singers, especially those with voices in the [[soprano]] range, in which Marchesi had specialized. ==Teachings== Marchesi was clearly committed to the bel canto style of singing. Despite this, she did not particularly identify herself as a bel canto teacher. She asserted that there were only two styles of singing: "the ''good''...and the ''bad''" and argued that a properly trained vocalist could sing the old bel canto style just as easily as the then newer, more dramatic style. She was generally an advocate of a naturalistic style of singing: she called for a fairly instinctive method of breathing and argued against the "smiling" mouth position that many teachers of her day preferred. She was particularly concerned with [[vocal registration]], calling it "the Alpha and Omega of the formation and development of the female voice, the touchstone of all singing methods, old and new." She also repeatedly expressed disdain for the teachers of her day who offered methods that they asserted would fully develop the voice in only a year or two. Instead, she felt that vocal training was best approached at a slow and deliberate pace. Two of the most distinctive features of her teachings were her "analytical method" and her insistence on very short practice times for beginners. Her "analytical method" placed great importance on intellectually understanding both the technical and the aesthetic nature of everything sung, from grand arias to simple vocal exercises. She argued that rote practice without understanding was ultimately harmful to the artistic use of the voice. Most distinctively, though, she insisted on very short practice times for beginners, as little as five minutes at a stretch three or four times a day for absolute beginners. Of course, as the voice matured those times could and should be expanded. ==Pupils== Among her pupils were: {{div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Suzanne Adams]] * [[Frances Alda]] * [[Sigrid Arnoldson]] * [[Blanche Arral]] * Kate Bensberg * Nadina Bulcioff * [[Emma Calvé]] * [[Ada Crossley]] * [[Ema Pukšec|Ilma de Murska]] * [[May De Sousa]] * Marie Duma * [[Emma Eames]] * Rose Ettinger * Antonietta Fricci * [[Mary Garden]] * [[Etelka Gerster]] * [[Louise Johnson-Missievitch]] * [[Jeanne Jomelli]] * [[Božena Kacerovská]] * [[Katharina Klafsky]] * [[Gabrielle Krauss]] * [[Selma Kurz]] * [[Miriam Licette]] * [[Estelle Liebling]] * Blanche Marchesi (her daughter) * Dame [[Nellie Melba]] * [[Yevgeniya Mravina]] * Louise Natali-Graham * [[Emma Nevada]] * [[Aglaja Orgeni]] * [[Gina Oselio]] * [[Regina Pacini]] * Rosa Papier * [[Anna Pessiak-Schmerling]] * Marta Petrini * Sedohr Rhodes * Louise Rieger * Caroline Salla * [[Sibyl Sanderson]] * Frances Saville * [[Evelyn Scotney]] * Nadina Slaviansky * [[Georgina Stirling]] * Maggie Stirling * Florence Toronta * Guillaume Tremelli * Inez McCune Williamson * [[Ellen Beach Yaw]] * [[Nadezhda Zabela-Vrubel]] {{div col end}} (Some pupils were noted on an 1899 dedicatory poster, ''Anniversary Fete – fifty years professorship, Mathilde Marchesi, 1849–1899''). ==Family== Her daughter, [[Blanche Marchesi]] (1863–1940), a [[contralto]], also a noted singer and teacher, made her début at a young age. She first appeared in opera at Prague in 1900, and subsequently sang at Covent Garden in 1902 and 1903. She was an admired concert singer. ==Notes== {{more footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{reflist}} ==References== * Marchesi, Mathilde. ''Bel Canto: A Theoretical and Practical Vocal Method''. Dover (1970). {{ISBN|0-486-22315-9}} * Marchesi, Mathilde. ''Marchesi and Music: Passages from the Life of a Famous Singing Teacher''. New York ; London : Harper & Bros. Publishers, 1898. * Marchesi, Mathilde. ''Ten Singing Lessons.'' Preface by Madame Melba, introduction by W. J. Henderson. New York ; London : Harper, 1901. *{{Cite EB1922|wstitle=Marchesi, Mathilde}} * Somerset-Ward, Richard. ''Angels & Monsters: Male and Female Sopranos in the Story of Opera'', (Chapter 10, "Marchesi's Pupils"). New Haven ; London : Yale University Press, 2004. {{ISBN|0-300-09968-1}} ==External links== * [http://catnyp.nypl.org/record=b1768271 The Marchesi Collection] contains many papers of Mathilde Marchesi, in the [http://www.nypl.org/musicdiv Music Division] of [https://web.archive.org/web/20091016095314/http://www.nypl.org/research/lpa/lpa.html The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts] * {{IMSLP|id=Marchesi, Mathilde}} * [http://scriabin.com/etude/1904/04/madame-marchesi---some-of-her-teaching-principles.html Madame Marchesi – Some of Her Teaching Principles], from [http://scriabin.com/etude/ The Etude Magazine], [http://scriabin.com/etude/1904/04/ April, 1904]. * [http://scriabin.com/etude/1913/10/truths-for-singing-teachers-and-students.html Truths for Singing Teachers and Students, by Mme. Mathilde Marchesi], from [http://scriabin.com/etude/ The Etude Magazine], [http://scriabin.com/etude/1913/10/ October, 1913]. {{Portal bar|Biography|Opera}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marchesi, Mathilde}} [[Category:1821 births]] [[Category:1913 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century German singers]] [[Category:German operatic mezzo-sopranos]] [[Category:Voice teachers]] [[Category:Vocal coaches]] [[Category:Pupils of Manuel García (baritone)]] [[Category:German emigrants to England]] [[Category:People from Frankfurt]] [[Category:19th-century women singers]]

Albă'') |Operators=*{{flagicon image|Naval ensign of Romania (1922-1947).svg}} [[Romanian Naval Forces]] *{{navy|Soviet Union}} |Class before=''[[NMS Alexandru cel Bun|Alexandru cel Bun]]''-class |operations=*[[Black Sea campaigns (1941–44)]] **[[Raid on Constanța]] **[[Crimean Offensive|Evacuation of the Crimea]] **[[Snake Island (Black Sea)#World War II|Snake Island Campaign]] **[[Romanian Navy during World War II|Romanian Navy during the Second World War]] |victories=*1 cruiser damaged *1 destroyer leader, 1 R-boat, 1 S-boat, 2 motor gunboats and up to 12 submarines sunk *12 aircraft destroyed |awards=*[[File:Order of the Crown of Romania-Ribbon 1932-1947.jpg|40px|Order of the Crown (Romania)]] [[Order of the Crown (Romania)]] *[[File:Star of Romania Ribbon.PNG|40px|Order of the *1,068 tons (full load) |Ship tons burthen= |Ship length={{convert|76.9|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|9.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|2.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=2 Krupp diesel engines {{convert|2,100|hp|kW|lk=in|abbr=on|order=flip}}, 2 shafts |Ship speed={{convert|16|kn|km/h mph|lk=in}} |Ship range={{convert|3,400|nmi|lk=in}} |Ship endurance= |Ship complement=135 |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*2 x 105 mm [[10.5 cm SK C/32 naval gun|SK C/32]] naval/AA guns *2 x 37 mm [[3.7 cm Flak 18/36/37/43|Rheinmetall]] AA guns *4 × 20 mm [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon|Oerlikon]] AA guns *2 × 13 mm [[Hotchkiss M1929 machine gun|M1929]] twin machine guns *2 x depth charge throwers *65 x depth charges *135 x mines *1 x motor launch armed with: **1 × 20 mm [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon|Oerlikon]] AA gun **1 x 8 mm machine gun **6 x depth charges }} |}
'''NMS ''Amiral Murgescu''''' was a [[minelayer]] and convoy escort of the [[Romanian Naval Forces|Romanian Navy]], the first sea-going warship built in Romania and the largest Romanian-built warship of [[World War II]]. She laid numerous minefields, from the Bulgarian port of [[Burgas]] to the Crimean port of [[Sevastopol]], which inflicted significant losses to the Soviet Black Sea Fleet. She also carried out numerous convoy escort missions and took part in the Axis evacuation of the Crimea in May 1944. Due to her success in combat, she was decorated twice by May 1944. She was captured by the [[Soviet Union]] in September 1944 and served until 1988, when she was scrapped.
==Description== [[File:Romanian minelayer Amiral Murgescu diagram.jpg|thumb|left|Diagram of ''Amiral Murgescu'' (note the gun shields which were removed after her first weeks of service)]] ''Amiral Murgescu'' was laid down on 1 August 1938 and launched on 14 June 1939.<ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Warship 1991'', Conway Maritime Press, 1991, p. 147</ref> Her full-load displacement amounted to 1,068 tons while her standard displacement was of 812 tons.<ref>''The Shipbuilder and Marine Engine-builder, Volume 46'', Shipbuilder Press, 1939, p. 449</ref> She measured 76.9 meters in length, with a beam of 9.1 meters and a draught of 2.5 meters. She was armed with two 105 mm [[10.5 cm SK C/32 naval gun|SK C/32]] dual-purpose naval/AA guns, two Rheinmetall 37 mm guns, four Oerlikon 20 mm guns and two twin 13 mm machine guns. She was also fitted with two depth charge throwers and could carry up to 200 mines and depth charges (135 mines and 65 depth charges).<ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922-1946'', Naval Institute Press, 1980, p. 362</ref><ref>Janusz Piekałkiewicz, ''Sea War, 1939-1945'', Historical Times, 1987, p. 350</ref><ref>John Campbell, ''Naval Weapons of World War Two'', Conway Maritime Press, 2002, p. 389</ref><ref>Frederick Thomas Jane, Maurice Brazil Prendergast, Oscar Parkes, ''Jane's Fighting Ships'', Jane's Publishing Company Limited, 1961, p. 198</ref><ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940-1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, p. 255 (in Romanian)</ref> Her two main guns were initially protected by gun shields, however these were removed in July 1941 in order to facilitate anti-aircraft fire.<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', p. 72</ref> ''Amiral Murgescu'' had a crew of up to 135 and was powered by two Krupp diesel engines generating 1,050 horse power each, giving her a top speed of 16 knots<ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922-1946'', Naval Institute Press, 1980, p. 362</ref> and a range of 3,400 nautical miles.<ref>''The Shipbuilder and Marine Engine-builder, Volume 46'', Shipbuilder Press, 1939, p. 449</ref>
===Motor launch=== ''Amiral Murgescu'' was also able to carry and operate one minesweeping motor launch. This launch was part of a [[Number 31-class motorboat|class of four]] 9-ton vessels armed each with one 20 mm anti-aircraft gun, one 8 mm machine gun and 6 depth charges.<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1941-1942'', Făt-Frumos, 1996, p. 183</ref><ref>Earl Thomas Allnutt Brassey, ''Brassey's Annual: The Armed Forces Year-book, Volume 58'', Praeger Publishers, 1947, p. 259</ref><ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940-1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, p. 259</ref>
==Service== [[File:Romanian minelayer Amiral Murgescu.jpg|thumb|left|''Amiral Murgescu'' (front view)]] [[File:Bundesarchiv N 1603 Bild-026, Konstanza, Minenleger "Amiral Murgescu" im Hafen.jpg|thumb|left|''Amiral Murgescu'' loaded with mines and ready to depart, Constanța, October 1941]] She had four captains across the war: Alexandru Dumbravă (1941–1942), Ovidiu Mărgineanu (1942–1943), Gheorghe Harting (1943) and Anton Foca (1943–1944).<ref>Constantin Cumpănă, Corina Apostoleanu, ''Amintiri despre o flota pierduta – vol. II – Voiaje neterminate'', 2011, Telegraf Advertising</ref>
''Amiral Murgescu'' was commissioned on 2 March 1941.<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1941-1942'', Făt-Frumos, 1996, p. 72</ref> Her first mission was between 16 and 19 June 1941, when she and two other Romanian minelayers, ''[[NMS Regele Carol I|Regele Carol I]]'' and ''[[NMS Aurora|Aurora]]'', laid a barrage of 1,000 mines between Cape Midia and [[Tuzla, Constanța|Tuzla]], to protect the main Romanian port of [[Constanța]]. When the Soviet Black Sea Fleet attacked the port on 26 June, she helped repel the attack, together with the [[flotilla leader]] ''[[NMS Mărăști|Mărăști]]'' and the destroyer ''[[Regele Ferdinand-class destroyer|Regina Maria]]'' and the [[German coastal battery Tirpitz]]. The Soviet destroyer leader ''Moskva'' was sunk by Romanian mines and the cruiser ''[[Soviet cruiser Voroshilov|Voroshilov]]'' was damaged. ''Amiral Murgescu'' also shot down two Soviet aircraft on that same day.<ref>Jonathan Trigg, ''Death on the Don: The Destruction of Germany's Allies on the Eastern Front'', Chapter 3</ref><ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', pp. 70 and 71</ref> Later, the Soviet submarine ''[[Soviet submarine Shch-213|Shch-213]]'' and 3 more Soviet submarines (''M-58'', ''M-34'' and ''Shch-208'') were sunk by Romanian mines near Constanța.<ref>Mikhail Monakov, Jurgen Rohwer, ''Stalin's Ocean-going Fleet: Soviet Naval Strategy and Shipbuilding Programs 1935–1953, pp. 265–266''</ref> The German [[R-boat]] ''R-36'' was also sunk by Romanian mines near Constanța in 1943.<ref>Gordon Smith, Don Kindell, Donald A. Bertke, ''World War II Sea War, Vol 9: Wolfpacks Muzzled'', p. 203</ref>
During a Soviet air raid on 23 June 1941, two of her crewmen were wounded. On a subsequent raid which took place the following day, she shot down two Soviet aircraft, her first aerial kills.<ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940–1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, pp. 45–46</ref>
On 25 June, ''Amiral Murgescu'' shot down three Soviet aircraft in 15 minutes.<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1941-1942'', Făt-Frumos, 1996, p. 105</ref>
During a Soviet air attack on Constanța on 5 August, she shot down three more aircraft.<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', p. 72</ref>
Her next mission was between 7 and 16 October 1941. Together with the Romanian minelayers ''Regele Carol I'' and ''Dacia'' and escorted by the Romanian [[250t-class torpedo boat|250t-class]] torpedo boats ''[[NMS Năluca|Năluca]]'', ''[[NMS Sborul|Sborul]]'' and ''Smeul'', Romanian gunboats ''[[NMS Sublocotenent Ghiculescu|Sublocotenent Ghiculescu]]'' and ''Căpitan Dumitrescu'' and Bulgarian torpedo boats [[Bulgarian torpedo boat Drazki|''Drazki'']], ''Smeli'' and ''Hrabri'', she laid four full minefields and one partial minefield along the Bulgarian coast.<ref>Donald A Bertke, Gordon Smith, Don Kindell, ''World War II Sea War, Volume 4: Germany Sends Russia to the Allies'', p. 323</ref> These mines later sank 4 Soviet submarines (''S-34'', ''L-24'', ''Shch-210'' and ''Shch-211'').<ref>Mikhail Monakov, Jurgen Rohwer, ''Stalin's Ocean-going Fleet: Soviet Naval Strategy and Shipbuilding Programs 1935–1953, pp. 265–266''</ref>
In February 1942, she participated in a minelaying operation near [[Sulina]], at the mouth of the [[Danube]].<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', p. 76</ref>
On 24 June 1942, she laid mines near Odessa along with ''Dacia'', while being escorted by the Romanian destroyers ''[[Regele Ferdinand-class destroyer|Regele Ferdinand]]'' and ''[[Regele Ferdinand-class destroyer|Regina Maria]]'', the flotilla leader ''[[NMS Mărășești|Mărășești]]'', the Romanian gunboats ''Ghiculescu'', ''Stihi'' and ''Dumitrescu'' and the Romanian torpedo boat ''[[NMS Smeul|Smeul]]'' as well as motor minesweepers of the Donau Flotilla.<ref>Donald A. Bertke, Gordon Smith, Don Kindell ''World War II Sea War, Volume 6: The Allies Halt the Axis Advance'', p. 268</ref> The mines laid near Odessa later sank the Soviet submarines ''M-33'' and ''M-60''<ref>Mikhail Monakov, Jurgen Rohwer, ''Stalin's Ocean-going Fleet: Soviet Naval Strategy and Shipbuilding Programs 1935–1953'', p. 266</ref> and the motor gunboats ''YA-26'' and ''YA-27''.<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1944–1945'', p. 365 (in Romanian)</ref><ref>[http://www.navypedia.org/ships/russia/ru_cf_ya5.htm Navypedia:Ya-5 and Ya-5M types motor mortar boats (1942–1945)]</ref>
On 29–30 October and 5 November 1942, she along with ''Dacia'' and the Romanian destroyers ''[[Regele Ferdinand-class destroyer|Regina Maria]]'' and ''[[Regele Ferdinand-class destroyer|Regele Ferdinand]]'', the Romanian leader ''[[NMS Mărăști|Mărăști]]'', the Romanian gunboat ''Stihi'' and four German [[R-boat]]s laid two mine barrages to protect [[Snake Island (Black Sea)|Snake Island]].<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1942–1944'', pp. 53–54 (in Romanian)</ref> These mines sank the Soviet submarine ''Shch-212'' on 11 December that same year.<ref>Donald A Bertke, Gordon Smith, Don Kindell,''World War II Sea War, Vol 8: Guadalcanal Secured'', p. 77</ref><ref>[http://uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/5043.html ''Shch-212'' on uboat.net]</ref><ref>[http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?170593 ''Shch-212'' on wrecksite.eu]</ref> The Soviet submarine ''M-31'' was either sunk as well by the Romanian mine barrages near the island on 17 December,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.navypedia.org/ships/russia/ru_ss_mxii.htm |work=Navypedia |title="Series XII" submarines (project 40) (1937–1943) |author=Gogin, Ivan |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= Helgason, Guðmundur |url=http://uboat.net/allies/warships/ship/4946.html |title=M-31 |work= uboat.net |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> or sunk with depth charges by the Romanian leader ''[[NMS Mărășești|Mărășești]]'' on 7 July 1943.<ref>M. J. Whitley, ''Destroyers of World War Two'', p. 224</ref> On 1 December 1942, while the Soviet cruiser ''[[Soviet cruiser Voroshilov|Voroshilov]]'' together with the destroyer ''Soobrazitelny'' were bombarding the island with forty-six 180 mm and fifty-seven 100 mm shells, the cruiser was damaged by Romanian mines, but she managed to return to [[Poti]] for repairs under her own power. During the brief bombardment, she struck the radio station, barracks and lighthouse on the island, but failed to inflict significant losses.<ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940–1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, pp. 93–94</ref><ref>Timothy C. Dowling, ''Russia at War: From the Mongol Conquest to Afghanistan, Chechnya, and Beyond'', p. 128</ref><ref>Spencer C. Tucker, ''World War II at Sea: An Encyclopedia'',. p. 114</ref><ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1942–1944'', p. 56 (in Romanian)</ref><ref>Yakubov, Vladimir; Worth, Richard (2009). ''The Soviet Light Cruisers of the Kirov Class''. In Jordan, John. ''Warship 2009'', p. 92</ref>
On the night of 13–14 September 1943, ''Amiral Murgescu'', escorted by two Romanian destroyers, laid mines off [[Sevastopol]].<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', p. 81</ref> On 15 September, she along with two German auxiliary minelayers, escorted by six [[R-boat]]s and the German armed ship ''Xanten'', laid a barrage of mines that closed the mouth of the Gulf of [[Kherson]].<ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940–1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, p. 120</ref>
When not used as minelayer, ''Amiral Murgescu'' was employed as an escort ship.<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', p. 80</ref><ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922-1946'', Naval Institute Press, 1980, p. 362</ref> She participated in a total of 16 escort missions, mainly between [[Constanța]] and [[Sevastopol]], between November 1942 and September 1943. One of these missions, on 19–20 July 1943, was carried out solely by her.<ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940-1945'', Ion Cristoiu Publishing, 2000, pp. 267-272</ref> On 15 April 1944, a convoy she was escorting during the [[Crimean Offensive|evacuation of the Crimea]] was attacked five times by Soviet bombers. She shot down two of them, but one of her main guns and one 20 mm gun were damaged.<ref>Nicolae Koslinski, Raymond Stănescu, ''Marina română in al doilea război mondial: 1942–1944'' (in Romanian)</ref><ref>Jipa Rotaru, Ioan Damaschin, ''Glorie și dramă: Marina Regală Română, 1940–1945'' (in Romanian), p. 138</ref>
On 12 May 1944, she was the last Romanian warship to leave Crimea during the [[Crimean Offensive|evacuation of the peninsula]] by the Axis. Commanded by Lieutenant Commander Anton Foca, she evacuated about 1,000 troops, including the highly decorated German General [[Walter Hartmann]].<ref>Robert Forczyk, ''Where the Iron Crosses Grow: The Crimea 1941–44'', Chapter 9</ref>
On 25–26 May, she and ''Dacia'', escorted by the destroyer ''Regina Maria'', the leader ''Mărășești'', the torpedo boats ''Sborul'' and ''Smeul'' and the motor torpedo boats ''[[NMS Vedenia|Vedenia]]'' and ''[[NMS Viscolul|Viscolul]]'', laid another barrage of mines off Sulina to reinforce the existing one.<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001–2002'', Conway Maritime Press, 2001, p. 84</ref> The mines laid off Sulina sank the German [[E-boat|S-boat]] ''S-148'' on 22 August 1944.<ref>Lawrence Paterson, ''Schnellboote: A Complete Operational History'', p. 261</ref>
On 29 May 1944, she was decorated with the [[Order of the Star of Romania]]. She was also decorated with the [[Order of the Crown (Romania)|Order of the Romanian Crown]].<ref>[http://www.ligamilitarilor.ro/arc-peste-timp/puitorul-de-nms-amiral-murgescu-al-doilea-razboi-mondial/ ''Amiral Murgescu'' (in Romanian)]</ref><ref>Constantin Cumpănă, Corina Apostoleanu, ''Amintiri despre o flota pierduta – vol. II – Voiaje neterminate'', 2011, Telegraf Advertising</ref>
After the [[King Michael's Coup|23 August 1944 coup]], she was captured by Soviet forces and commissioned as ''Don''.<ref>Mikhail Monakov, Jurgen Rohwer, ''Stalin's Ocean-going Fleet: Soviet Naval Strategy and Shipbuilding Programs 1935–1953'', p. 167</ref> She was converted to training ship on 2 April 1945, to depot ship on 18 January 1947, to command ship on 9 February 1948, to disarmed barracks ship on 7 May 1956 (renamed ''PKZ-107'') and finally to repair ship on 4 January 1958 (renamed ''PM-76'', ''PMR-76'' from 8 June 1966), being finally taken out of service on 27 May 1988 and sold for scrap on 4 July 1988.<ref>[http://www.navypedia.org/ships/russia/ru_ms_don.htm Navypedia: ''DON'' minelayer (1941/1944)]</ref><ref>Jurgen Rohwer, ''Stalin's Ocean-going Fleet'', Routledge, 2017, p. 271</ref>
==''Cetatea Albă''== Four ships of this class were planned, but only ''Amiral Murgescu'' was completed by Romania.<ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922-1946'', Naval Institute Press, 1980, p. 362</ref> She had one sister ship, ''Cetatea Albă''. She was laid down in 1939, but abandoned at an early stage.<ref>''Naval Institute Proceedings, Volume 65'', United States Naval Institute, 1939, p. 1364</ref><ref>Robert Gardiner, ''Warship 1991'', Conway Maritime Press, 1991, p. 147</ref> Her construction was transferred to [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] and in 1940 she was completed by the [[Blohm & Voss]] shipyard in [[Hamburg]].<ref>Earl Thomas Allnutt Brassey, ''Brassey's Annual: The Armed Forces Year-book, Volume 58'', Praeger Publishers, 1947, p. 259</ref> ''Cetatea Albă'' had the same standard displacement and top speed as her sister. It is not known, however, if her armament consisted of more than two four-inch (102 mm) dual-purpose main guns, two 37 mm anti-aircraft guns and 135 mines.<ref>Earl Thomas Allnutt Brassey, ''Brassey's Annual: The Armed Forces Year-book, Volume 58'', Praeger Publishers, 1947, p. 259</ref> ''Cetatea Albă'' was likely never commissioned.<ref>[http://www.navypedia.org/ships/romania/ro_ms_murgescu.htm AMIRAL MURGESCU minelayers (1941), ''Navypedia'']</ref>
==Cancelled sister ships and their replacements== The other two planned vessels were replaced by smaller warships. One of the substitutes was the old but recently rebuilt minelayer ''[[NMS Aurora|Aurora]]'', commissioned in 1939. With a top speed of 20 knots, she was faster than ''Amiral Murgescu'', but far less suitable for escort missions: her small size allowed for only two twin 13 mm machine guns to be carried, in addition to her load of 40 mines. The other replacement was the ex-French gunboat ''Remus Lepri'', built in 1917. She was acquired by Romania after the end of [[World War I]], along with three sister ships. This 400-ton gunboat, part of the ''[[NMS Sublocotenent Ghiculescu|Ghiculescu]]''-class, was also fitted with minelaying equipment. However, she proved to be unsuitable as a minelayer, being accidentally sunk by an explosion during trials on 11 January 1941.<ref>Antony Preston, ''Warship 2001-2002'', Conway Maritime Press, 2001, p. 88</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Amiral Murgescu}} [[Category:Ships built in Romania]] [[Category:Captured ships]] [[Category:Minelayers of the Romanian Naval Forces]] [[Category:World War II minelayers of Romania]] [[Category:World War II mine warfare vessels of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Training ships]] [[Category:Auxiliary ships of the Soviet Navy]]
