{{merge|Telemedicine|discuss=Talk:Telehealth#Merger_proposal|date=October 2017}} {{merge|eHealth|discuss=Talk:Telehealth#Merger_proposal|date=October 2017}}
'''Telehealth''' involves the distribution of [[Health care|health-related services]] and information via electronic information and [[Telecommunication|telecommunication technologies]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hrsa.gov/healthit/toolbox/RuralHealthITtoolbox/Telehealth/index.html|title=TeleHealth|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=The Health Resources and Services Administration|access-date=}}</ref> It allows long distance patient/clinician contact and care, advice, reminders, education, intervention, monitoring and remote admissions.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Shaw|first=Donald K|date=2009-06-01|title=Overview of Telehealth and Its Application to Cardiopulmonary Physical Therapy|journal=Cardiopulmonary Physical Therapy Journal|volume=20|issue=2|pages=13–18|issn=1541-7891|pmc=2845264|pmid=20467533}}</ref> As well as provider distance-learning; meetings, supervision, and presentations between practitioners; online information and [[health data]] management and healthcare system integration.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Miller|first=Edward Alan|date=2007-07-01|title=Solving the disjuncture between research and practice: telehealth trends in the 21st century|journal=Health Policy (Amsterdam, Netherlands)|volume=82|issue=2|pages=133–141|doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2006.09.011|issn=0168-8510|pmid=17046097}}</ref> Telehealth could include two [[clinician]]s discussing a case over [[Videoconferencing|video conference]]; a robotic surgery occurring through remote access; physical therapy done via digital monitoring instruments, live feed and application combinations; tests being forwarded between facilities for interpretation by a higher specialist; home monitoring through continuous sending of patient [[health data]]; client to practitioner online conference; or even videophone interpretation during a consult.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
As the population grows and ages, and medical advances are made which prolong life, demands increase on the healthcare system. Healthcare providers are also being asked to do more, with no increase in funding, or are encouraged to move to new models of funding and care such as patient-centered or outcomes based, rather than fee-for-service. Some specific health professions already have a shortage (i.e. Speech-language pathologists). When rural settings, lack of transport, lack of mobility (i.e. In the elderly or disabled), decreased funding or lack of staffing restrict access to care, telehealth can bridge the gap.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mashima|first=Pauline A.|last2=Doarn|first2=Charles R.|date=2008-12-01|title=Overview of telehealth activities in speech-language pathology|journal=Telemedicine Journal and E-Health: The Official Journal of the American Telemedicine Association|volume=14|issue=10|pages=1101–1117|doi=10.1089/tmj.2008.0080|issn=1556-3669|pmid=19119834}}</ref>
== Telehealth versus telemedicine == {{Main article|Telemedicine}}
Telehealth is sometimes discussed interchangeably with telemedicine. The [[Health Resources and Services Administration]] distinguishes telehealth from telemedicine in its scope. According to them, telemedicine only describes remote clinical services; such as diagnosis and monitoring, while telehealth includes preventative, promotive and curative care delivery.<ref name=":0" /> This includes the above-mentioned non-clinical applications like administration and provider education which make telehealth the preferred modern terminology.<ref name=":1" />
== History == The development and history of telehealth or telemedicine (terms used interchangeably in literature) is deeply rooted in the history and development in not only technology but also society itself. Humans have long sought to relay important messages through [[torch]]es, [[Semaphore line|optical telegraphy]], [[Electroscope|electroscopes,]] and [[Wireless|wireless transmission]]. In the 21st century, with the advent of the [[internet]], [[Portable communications device|portable devices]] and other such digital devices are taking a transformative role in healthcare and its delivery.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8jNbPgAACAAJ|title=History of Telemedicine: Evolution, Context, and Transformation|last=Bashshur|first=Rashid|last2=Shannon|first2=Gary William|date=2009-01-01|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert|isbn=9781934854112|language=en}}</ref>
=== Earliest instances === Although, [[traditional medicine]] relies on in-person care, the need and want for remote care has existed from the Roman and pre-Hippocratic periods in antiquity. The elderly and infirm who could not visit temples for medical care sent representatives to convey information on symptoms and bring home a diagnosis as well as treatment.<ref name=":3" /> In Africa, villagers would use [[smoke signal]]s to warn neighbouring villages of disease outbreak.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Nakajima|first=I.|last2=Sastrokusumo|first2=U.|last3=Mishra|first3=S. K.|last4=Komiya|first4=R.|last5=Malik|first5=A. Z.|last6=Tanuma|first6=T.|date=2006-08-01|title=The Asia Pacific telecommunity's telemedicine activities|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=1717870|journal=HEALTHCOM 2006 8th International Conference on e-Health Networking, Applications and Services|pages=280–282|doi=10.1109/HEALTH.2006.246471}}</ref> The beginnings of telehealth have existed through primitive forms of communication and technology.<ref name=":3" />
=== 1800s to early 1900s === As technology developed and wired communication became increasingly commonplace, the ideas surrounding telehealth began emerging. The earliest telehealth encounter can be traced to [[Alexander Graham Bell]] in 1876, when he used his early telephone as a means of getting help from his assistant Mr. Watson after he spilt acid on his trousers. Another instance of early telehealth, specifically telemedicine was reported in ''[[The Lancet]]'' in 1879. An anonymous writer described a case where a doctor successfully diagnosed a child over the telephone in the middle of the night.<ref name=":3" /> This Lancet issue, also further discussed the potential of Remote Patient Care in order to avoid unnecessary house visits, which were part of routine health care during the 1800s.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Zundel|first=K M|date=1996-01-01|title=Telemedicine: history, applications, and impact on librarianship.|journal=Bulletin of the Medical Library Association|volume=84|issue=1|pages=71–79|issn=0025-7338|pmc=226126|pmid=8938332}}</ref> Other instances of telehealth during this period came from the [[American Civil War]], during which telegraphs were used to deliver mortality lists and medical care to soldiers.<ref name=":5" />
From the late 1800s to the early 1900s the early foundations of [[Wireless|wireless communication]] were laid down.<ref name=":3" /> [[Radio]]s provided an easier and near instantaneous form of communication. The use of radio to deliver healthcare became accepted for remote areas.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T8gwu1okBW4C|title=E-Health, Telehealth, and Telemedicine: A Guide to Startup and Success|last=Maheu|first=Marlene|last2=Whitten|first2=Pamela|last3=Allen|first3=Ace|date=2002-02-28|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780787959036|language=en}}</ref> The [[Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia]] is an example of the early adoption of radios in telehealth.<ref name=":4" />
=== Mid-1900s to 1980s === When the American [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)]], began plans to send astronauts into space, the need for Telemedicine became clear. In order to monitor their astronauts in space, telemedicine capabilities were built into the [[spacecraft]] as well as the first [[Space suit|spacesuits]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6" /> Additionally, during this period, telehealth and Telemedicine were promoted in different countries especially the United States and Canada.<ref name=":3" />
In 1964, the Nebraska Psychiatric Institute began using television links to form two-way communication with the Norfolk State Hospital which was 112 miles away for the education and consultation purposes between clinicians in the two locations.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://electronicdesign.com/components/brief-history-telemedicine|title=A Brief History Of Telemedicine|last=Allan|first=Roger|date=|website=|publisher=Electronic Design|access-date=}}</ref> The [[Logan International Airport]] in Boston established in-house medical stations in 1967. These stations were linked to [[Massachusetts General Hospital]]. Clinicians at the hospital would provide consultation services to patients who were at the airport. Consultations were achieved through microwave audio as well as video links.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" />
In 1972 the [[United States Department of Health, Education, and Welfare|Department of Health, Education and Welfare]] in the United States approved funding for seven telemedicine projects across different states. This funding was renewed and two further projects were funded the following year.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" />
=== 1980s to 1990s – maturation and renaissance === Telehealth projects underway before and during the 1980s would take off but fail to enter mainstream healthcare.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /> As a result, this period of telehealth history is called the "maturation" stage and made way for sustainable growth.<ref name=":3" /> Although State funding in North America was beginning to run low, different hospitals began to launch their own telehealth initiatives.<ref name=":3" /> Additionally, NASA started experimenting with their ATS-3 satellite. Eventually, NASA started their SateLife/[[Health Net|HealthNet]] programme which tried to increase the health services connectivity in developing countries.<ref name=":6" />
=== 2000s and onward === The combination of sustained growth, the advent of the [[internet]] and the increasing adoption of [[Information and communications technology|ICT]] in traditional methods of care spurred the revival or "renaissance" of telehealth.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://cchpca.org/what-is-telehealth.|title=What is Telehealth?|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=The Center for Connected Health Policy|access-date=}}</ref> The diffusion of portable devices like laptops and mobile devices in everyday life made ideas surrounding telehealth more plausible. Telehealth is no longer bound within the realms of telemedicine but has expanded itself to promotion, prevention and education.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":6" />
== Methods and modalities == Telehealth requires a strong, reliable [[broadband]] connection. The broadband signal transmission infrastructure includes wires, cables, microwaves and [[Optical fiber|optic fibre]], which must be maintained for the provision of telehealth services. The better the connection (bandwidth quality), the more data can be sent and received. Historically this has priced providers or patients out of the service, but as the infrastructure improves and becomes more accessible, telehealth usage can grow.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
When a healthcare service decides to provide telehealth to its patients, there are steps to consider, besides just whether the above resources are available. A [[needs assessment]] is the best way to start, which includes assessing the access the community currently has to the proposed specialists and care, whether the organisation currently has underutilized equipment which will make them useful to the area they are trying to service, and the hardships they are trying to improve by providing the access to their intended community (i.e. Travel time, costs, time off work).<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> A service then needs to consider potential collaborators. Other services may exist in the area with similar goals who could be joined to provide a more holistic service, and/or they may already have telehealth resources available. The more services involved, the easier to spread the cost of IT, training, workflow changes and improve [[Management|buy-in]] from clients. Services need to have the patience to wait for the accrued benefits of providing their telehealth service and cannot necessarily expect community-wide changes reflected straight away.<ref name=":0" />
Once the need for a Telehealth service is established, delivery can come within four distinct domains. They are [[Live video streaming|live video (synchronous)]], [[Store and forward|store-and-forward (asynchronous)]], [[remote patient monitoring]], and [[MHealth|mobile health]]. Live video involves a real-time two-way interaction, such as patient/caregiver-provider or provider-provider, over a digital (i.e. [[broadband]]) connection. This often is used to substitute a face to face meeting such as consults, and saves time and cost in travel. [[Store and forward|Store-and-forward]] is when data is collected, recorded, and then sent on to a provider.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":8" /> For example, a patient's' digital health history file including x-rays and notes, being securely transmitted electronically to evaluate the current case. [[Remote patient monitoring]] includes patients' medical and [[health data]] being collected and transferred to a provider elsewhere who can continue to monitor the data and any changes that may occur. This may best suit cases that require ongoing care such as rehabilitation, chronic care, or elderly clients trying to stay in the community in their own homes as opposed to a care facility. Mobile health includes any health information, such as education, monitoring and care, that is present on and supported by mobile communication devices such as [[Mobile phone|cell phones]] or [[tablet computer]]s. This might include an [[Mobile app|application]], or [[Text messaging|text messaging services]] like appointment reminders or public health warning systems.<ref name=":8" />
== Major developments ==
=== In policy === Telehealth is a modern form of health care delivery. Telehealth breaks away from traditional health care delivery by using modern telecommunication systems including wireless communication methods.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vZNEMwEACAAJ|title=Telehealth Practice in Eight Countries: New Zealand, Australia, the USA, Canada, UK, Malaysia, China and India : a Thesis Presented in Partial Fulfillment of the Requirements of Degree of Master in Information Science at Massey University, Albany Campus, Auckland, New Zealand|date=2012-01-01|publisher=Massey University, Albany|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=García-Rojo|first=Marcial|title=International Clinical Guidelines for the Adoption of Digital Pathology: A Review of Technical Aspects|url=http://www.karger.com/?doi=10.1159/000441192|journal=Pathobiology|volume=83|issue=2-3|pages=99–109|doi=10.1159/000441192}}</ref> Traditional health is legislated through policy to ensure the safety of medical practitioners and patients. Consequently, since telehealth is a new form of health care delivery that is now gathering momentum in the health sector, many organizations have started to legislate the use of telehealth into policy.<ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keshvari|first=Hamid|last2=Haddadpoor|first2=Asefeh|last3=Taheri|first3=Behjat|last4=Nasri|first4=Mehran|last5=Aghdak|first5=Pezhman|date=2014-01-01|title=Survey Determinant Factors of Telemedicine Strategic Planning from the Managers and Experts Perspective in the Health Department, Isfahan University of Medical Sciences|url=http://www.scopemed.org/?mno=172066|journal=Acta Informatica Medica|volume=22|issue=5|doi=10.5455/aim.2014.22.320-324|pmc=4272851|pmid=25568581|pages=320}}</ref> In New Zealand, the Medical Council has a statement about telehealth on their website. This illustrates that the medical council has foreseen the importance that telehealth will have on the health system and have started to introduce telehealth legislation to practitioners along with government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcnz.org.nz/assets/News-and-Publications/Statement-on-telehealthv3.pdf|title=Statement on telehealth|last=|first=|date=2013|website=|publisher=Medical Council of New Zealand|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Transition to mainstream === {{See also|Remote patient monitoring}}
Traditional use of telehealth services has been for specialist treatment. However, there has been a paradigm shift and telehealth is no longer considered a specialist service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hiirc.org.nz/page/41996/clinicians-perceptions-of-telemedicine-opportunities/;jsessionid=7A7875E69BE51E62E5C9527426776857?tag=informationtechnology&tab=4180&contentType=167&section=9088|title=Clinicians' perceptions of telemedicine: Opportunities and barriers for emergency medicine • Health Improvement and Innovation Resource Centre|website=www.hiirc.org.nz|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref> This development has ensured that many access barriers are eliminated, as medical professionals are able to use wireless communication technologies to deliver health care.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Laxman|first=Kumar|date=2015|title=Barriers to Adoption of Consumer Health Informatics Applications for Health Self Management|url=|journal=Health Science Journal|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> This is evident in rural communities. For individuals living in rural communities, specialist care can be some distance away, particularly in the next major city. Telehealth eliminates this barrier, as health professionals are able to conduct a medical consultation through the use of wireless communication technologies. However, this process is dependent on both parties having Internet access.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Possemato|first=Kyle|last2=Bishop|first2=Todd M.|last3=Willis|first3=Matthew A.|last4=Lantinga|first4=Larry J.|date=2013-04-25|title=Healthcare Utilization and Symptom Variation Among Veterans Using Behavioral Telehealth Center Services|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11414-013-9338-y|journal=The Journal of Behavioral Health Services & Research|language=en|volume=40|issue=4|pages=416–426|doi=10.1007/s11414-013-9338-y|issn=1094-3412}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Darkins|first=Adam|last2=Foster|first2=Linda|last3=Anderson|first3=Carla|last4=Goldschmidt|first4=Leonard|last5=Selvin|first5=Gerald|date=2013-07-01|title=The design, implementation, and operational management of a comprehensive quality management program to support national telehealth networks|journal=Telemedicine Journal and E-Health: The Official Journal of the American Telemedicine Association|volume=19|issue=7|pages=557–564|doi=10.1089/tmj.2012.0263|issn=1556-3669|pmid=23705961}}</ref>
Telehealth allows the patient to be monitored between physician office visits which can improve patient health. Telehealth also allows patients to access expertise which is not available in their local area. This remote patient monitoring ability enables patients to stay at home longer and helps avoid unnecessary hospital time. In the long-term, this could potentially result in less burdening of the healthcare system and consumption of resources.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":6" />
=== Technology advancement === {{see also|Technology|Emerging technologies}}
The technological advancement of wireless communication devices is a major development in telehealth.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Vockley|first=Martha|date=2015-10-01|title=The Rise of Telehealth: 'Triple Aim,' Innovative Technology, and Popular Demand Are Spearheading New Models of Health and Wellness Care|journal=Biomedical Instrumentation & Technology|volume=49|issue=5|pages=306–320|doi=10.2345/0899-8205-49.5.306|issn=0899-8205|pmid=26443907}}</ref> This allows patients to self-monitor their health conditions and to not rely as much on health care professionals. Furthermore, patients are more willing to stay on their treatment plans as they are more invested and included in the process, decision-making is shared.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Kvedar|first=Joseph|last2=Coye|first2=Molly Joel|last3=Everett|first3=Wendy|date=2014-02-01|title=Connected health: a review of technologies and strategies to improve patient care with telemedicine and telehealth|journal=Health Affairs (Project Hope)|volume=33|issue=2|pages=194–199|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2013.0992|issn=1544-5208|pmid=24493760}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Hirani|first=Shashivadan P.|last2=Rixon|first2=Lorna|last3=Beynon|first3=Michelle|last4=Cartwright|first4=Martin|last5=Cleanthous|first5=Sophie|last6=Selva|first6=Abi|last7=Sanders|first7=Caroline|last8=Newman|first8=Stanton P.|date=2016-05-25|title=Quantifying beliefs regarding telehealth: Development of the Whole Systems Demonstrator Service User Technology Acceptability Questionnaire|url=http://jtt.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/05/25/1357633X16649531|journal=Journal of Telemedicine and Telecare|language=en|pages=1357633X16649531|doi=10.1177/1357633X16649531|issn=1357-633X|pmid=27224997}}</ref> Technological advancement also means that health care professionals are able to use better technologies to treat patients for example in [[surgery]]. Technological developments in telehealth are essential to improve health care, especially the delivery of healthcare services, as resources are finite along with an ageing population that is living longer.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" />
== Major implications and impacts == Telehealth allows multiple, different disciplines to merge and deliver a much more uniform level of care using the efficiency and accessibility of everyday technology. As telehealth proliferates mainstream healthcare and challenges notions of traditional healthcare delivery, different populations are starting to experience better quality, access and personalised care in their lives.<ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Books-Telemental-Health-Administrative-Foundations-Evidence-Based/dp/0124160484|title=Telemental Health: Clinical, Technical, and Administrative Foundations for Evidence-Based Practice|date=2012-09-20|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780124160484|editor-last=Professor|editor-first=Kathleen Myers|edition=1|language=English|editor-last2=Professor|editor-first2=Carolyn Turvey}}</ref><ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Umefjord|first=Göran|date=2006-01-01|title=Internet consultation in medicine : studies of a text-based Ask the doctor service|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/279663013_Internet_consultation_in_medicine_studies_of_a_text-based_Ask_the_doctor_service}}</ref>
=== Health promotion === ''See Also: [[Health promotion|Health Promotion]]'' [[File:SmallWorldSocial BreastfeedingSupportProject GeorgiawithBabyEve.jpg|thumb|Baby Eve with Georgia for the Breastfeeding Support Project]]Telehealth can also increase health promotion efforts. These efforts can now be more personalised to the target population and professionals can extend their help into homes or private and safe environments in which patients of individuals can practice, ask and gain health information.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":13" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kahn|first=Jeremy M.|date=2015-04-30|title=Virtual visits--confronting the challenges of telemedicine|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=372|issue=18|pages=1684–1685|doi=10.1056/NEJMp1500533|issn=1533-4406|pmid=25923547}}</ref> Health promotion using telehealth has become increasingly popular in [[Developing country|underdeveloped countries]] where there are very poor physical resources available. There has been a particular push toward [[mHealth]] applications as many areas, even underdeveloped ones have mobile phone coverage.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQ74YyKYpNMC|title=Cell Phone Culture: Mobile Technology in Everyday Life|last=Goggin|first=Gerard|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415367431|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/mhealth-in-practice-9781780932293/|title=mHealth in Practice|last=Bloomsbury.com|website=Bloomsbury Publishing|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref>
In [[Developed country|developed countries]], health promotion efforts using telehealth have been met with some success. The [[Google Glass breastfeeding app trial|Australian hands-free breastfeeding Google Glass application]] reported promising results in 2014. This application made in collaboration with the Australian Breastfeeding Association and a tech startup called [[Small World Social]], helped new mothers learn how to [[Breastfeeding|breastfeed]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hlntv.com/article/2014/04/23/breastfeeding-google-glass-app?sr=fb042414breastfeed10photolink.|title=Google Glass can help you breastfeed|last=|first=|date=2014|website=|publisher=HLN Staff|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.breastfeeding.asn.au/breastfeeding-and-google-glass-application-trial|title=Breastfeeding and Google Glass application trial|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|publisher=The Australian Breastfeeding Association|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.smallworldsocial.com/breastfeeding-support-project/.|title=Breastfeeding Support Program Through Gooogle Glass|last=|first=|date=2015|website=|publisher=Small World|access-date=}}</ref> Breastfeeding is beneficial to infant health and [[maternal health]] and is recommended by the [[World Health Organization|World Health Organisation]] and health organisations all over the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/maternal_child_adolescent/documents/9241595230/en/|title=WHO {{!}} Evidence on the long-term effects of breastfeeding|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref><ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Victora|first=Cesar G.|last2=Bahl|first2=Rajiv|last3=Barros|first3=Aluísio J. D.|last4=França|first4=Giovanny V. A.|last5=Horton|first5=Susan|last6=Krasevec|first6=Julia|last7=Murch|first7=Simon|last8=Sankar|first8=Mari Jeeva|last9=Walker|first9=Neff|date=2016-01-30|title=Breastfeeding in the 21st century: epidemiology, mechanisms, and lifelong effect|journal=Lancet|volume=387|issue=10017|pages=475–490|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(15)01024-7|issn=1474-547X|pmid=26869575}}</ref> Widespread breastfeeding can prevent 820,000 infant deaths globally but the practice is often stopped prematurely or intents to do are disrupted due to lack of social support, know-how or other factors.<ref name=":17" /> This application gave mother's hands-free information on breastfeeding, instructions on how to breastfeed and also had an option to call a lactation consultant over Google Hangout. When the trial ended, all participants were reported to be confident in breastfeeding.<ref name=":16" />
=== Health care quality === {{See also|Health care quality|l1=Health Care Quality}}
Theoretically, the whole health system stands to benefit from telehealth. In a UK telehealth trial done in 2011, it was reported that the cost of health could be dramatically reduced with the use of telehealth monitoring. The usual cost of [[in vitro fertilisation]] (IVF) per cycle would be around $15,000, with telehealth it was reduced to $800 per patient.<ref>Chausiaux O, Hayes J, Long C, Morris S, Williams G, Husheer S. Pregnancy Prognosis in Infertile Couples on the DuoFertility Programme Compared with In Vitro Fertilisation/Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection. European Obstetrics & Gynaecology 2011;6(2):92-94.</ref> In [[Alaska Federal Health Care Access Network|Alaska the Federal Health Care Access Network]] which connects 3,000 healthcare providers to communities, engaged in 160,000 telehealth consultations from 2001 and saved the state $8.5 million in travel costs for just [[Medicaid]] patients.<ref>The Innovations Exchange Team. Telehealth Improves Access and Quality of Care for Alaska Natives. 2013; Available at: <nowiki>https://innovations.ahrq.gov/perspectives/telehealth-improves-access-and-quality-care-alaska-natives</nowiki>.</ref> There are indications telehealth consumes fewer resources and requires fewer people to operate it with shorter training periods to implement initiatives.<ref name=":8" />
However, whether or not the standard of health care quality is increasing is quite debatable, with literature refuting such claims.<ref name=":15" /><ref name=":18">Bardsley M, Steventon A, Doll H. Impact of telehealth on general practice contacts: findings from the whole systems demonstrator cluster randomised trial. BMC health services research 2013;13(1):1.</ref><ref>Cartwright M, Hirani SP, Rixon L, Beynon M, Doll H, Bower P, et al. Effect of telehealth on quality of life and psychological outcomes over 12 months (Whole Systems Demonstrator telehealth questionnaire study): nested study of patient reported outcomes in a pragmatic, cluster randomised controlled trial. BMJ 2013 Feb 26;346:f653.</ref> Research is increasingly reporting that clinicians find the process difficult and complex to deal with.<ref name=":18" /><ref>Sanders C, Rogers A, Bowen R, Bower P, Hirani S, Cartwright M, et al. Exploring barriers to participation and adoption of telehealth and telecare within the Whole System Demonstrator trial: a qualitative study. BMC Health Serv Res 2012 Jul 26;12:220-6963-12-220</ref> Furthermore, there are concerns around informed consent, legality issues as well as legislative issues. Although health care may become affordable with the help of technology, whether or not this care will be "good" is the issue.<ref name=":15" />
== Economic evaluations == Due to its digital nature it is often assumed that telehealth saves the health system money. However, the evidence to support this is varied. When conducting economic evaluations of telehealth services, the individuals evaulating them need to be aware of potential outcomes and extraclinical benefits of the telehealth service<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Snoswell|first=Centaine|last2=Smith|first2=Anthony C|last3=Scuffham|first3=Paul A|last4=Whitty|first4=Jennifer A|date=2016-10-27|title=Economic evaluation strategies in telehealth: Obtaining a more holistic valuation of telehealth interventions|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fjournals.sagepub.com%2Fdoi%2F10.1177%2F1357633X16671407|journal=Journal of Telemedicine and Telecare|language=en|volume=23|issue=9|pages=792–796|doi=10.1177/1357633x16671407|issn=1357-633X}}</ref>.
== Nonclinical uses == * [[Distance education]] including continuing medical education, grand rounds, and patient education * administrative uses including meetings among telehealth networks, supervision, and presentations * research on telehealth * online information and [[health data]] management * healthcare system integration * asset identification, listing, and patient to asset matching, and movement * overall healthcare system management * patient movement and remote admission
== Limitations and restrictions ==
While many branches of medicine have wanted to fully embrace telehealth for a long time, there are certain risks and barriers which bar the full amalgamation of telehealth into [[best practice]]. For a start, it is dubious as to whether a practitioner can fully leave the "hands-on" experience behind.<ref name=":15" /> Although it is predicted that telehealth will replace many consultations and other health interactions, it cannot yet fully replace a physical examination, this is particularly so in [[Medical diagnosis|diagnostics]], [[Physical medicine and rehabilitation|rehabilitation]] or [[mental health]].<ref name=":15" />
The benefits posed by telehealth challenge the normative means of healthcare delivery set in both legislation and practice. Therefore, the growing prominence of telehealth is starting to underscore the need for updated regulations, guidelines and legislation which reflect the current and future trends of healthcare practices.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":15" /> Telehealth enables timely and flexible care to patients wherever they may be; although this is a benefit, it also poses threats to [[privacy]], [[safety]][[Medical license|, medical licensing]] and [[reimbursement]]. When a clinician and patient are in different locations, it is difficult to determine which laws apply to the context.<ref>Keck CS, Doarn CR. Telehealth technology applications in speech-language pathology. Telemed J E Health 2014 Jul;20(7):653-659.</ref> Once healthcare crosses borders different state bodies are involved in order to regulate and maintain the level of care that is warranted to the patient or telehealth consumer. As it stands, telehealth is complex with many grey areas when put into practice especially as it crosses borders. This effectively limits the potential benefits of telehealth.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":15" />
An example of these limitations include the current American reimbursement infrastructure, where [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] will reimburse for telehealth services only when a patient is living in an area where specialists are in shortage, or in particular rural counties. The area is defined by whether it is a medical facility as opposed to a patient's' home. The site that the practitioner is in, however, is unrestricted. Medicare will only reimburse live video (synchronous) type services, not store-and-forward, mhealth or remote patient monitoring (if it does not involve live-video). Some insurers currently will reimburse telehealth, but not all yet. So providers and patients must go to the extra effort of finding the correct insurers before continuing. Again in America, states generally tend to require that clinicians are licensed to practice in the surgery' state, therefore they can only provide their service if licensed in an area that they do not live in themselves.<ref name=":0" />
More specific and widely reaching laws, legislations and regulations will have to evolve with the technology. They will have to be fully agreed upon, for example, will all clinicians need full licensing in every community they provide telehealth services too, or could there be a limited use telehealth licence? Would the limited use licence cover all potential telehealth interventions, or only some? Who would be responsible if an emergency was occurring and the practitioner could not provide immediate help – would someone else have to be in the room with the patient at all consult times? Which state, city or country would the law apply in when a breach or malpractice occurred? <ref name=":15" /><ref name=":19">Paul DL. Collaborative activities in virtual settings: A knowledge management perspective of telemedicine. J Manage Inf Syst 2006;22(4):143-176.</ref>
A major legal action prompt in telehealth thus far has been issues surrounding online prescribing and whether an appropriate clinician-patient relationship can be established online to make prescribing safe, making this an area that requires particular scrutiny.<ref name=":14" /> It may be required that the practitioner and patient involved must meet in person at least once before online prescribing can occur, or that at least a live-video conference must occur, not just impersonal questionnaires or surveys to determine need.<ref name=":20">Cascella LM. Virtual Risk: An Overview of Telehealth From a Risk Management Perspective. 2016.</ref>
== Ethical issues == {{see also|Informed consent|Medical ethics}}
''[[Informed consent]]'' is another issue – should the patient give informed consent to receive online care before it starts? Or will it be implied if it is care that can only practically be given over distance? When telehealth includes the possibility for technical problems such as transmission errors or security breaches or storage which impact on ability to communicate, it may be wise to obtain informed consent in person first, as well as having backup options for when technical issues occur. In person, a patient can see who is involved in their care (namely themselves and their clinician in a consult), but online there will be other involved such as the technology providers, therefore consent may need to involve disclosure of anyone involved in the transmission of the information and the security that will keep their information private, and any legal malpractice cases may need to involve all of those involved as opposed to what would usually just be the practitioner.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":19" /><ref name=":20" />
== The state of the market ==
The rate of adoption of telehealth services in any jurisdiction is frequently influenced by factors such as the adequacy and cost of existing conventional [[health care|health services]] in meeting [[patient|patient needs]]; the policies of governments and/or insurers with respect to coverage and payment for telehealth services; and medical licensing requirements that may inhibit or deter the provision of telehealth second opinions or primary consultations by physicians.
Projections for the growth of the telehealth market are optimistic, and much of this optimism is predicated upon the increasing demand for remote medical care. According to a recent survey, nearly three-quarters of U.S. consumers say they would use telehealth.<ref name="healthdata">{{cite web|url=http://www.healthdatamanagement.com/news/telemedicine-38701-1.html|title=Survey: Consumers Keen on Telemedicine|accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref> At present, several major companies along with a bevvy of startups are working to develop a leading presence in the field.
In the UK, the Government's Care Services minister, Paul Burstow, has stated that telehealth and telecare would be extended over the next five years (2012–2017) to reach three million people.

Gilman, M., & Stensland, J. Telehealth and Medicare: Payment Policy, Current Use, and Prospects for Growth.

{{notability|date=September 2018}} {{Anchor|Theatrezone}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Theatrezonelogo.gif|right|thumb|200px|Theatre Zone Logo]] --> '''TheatreZone''' is a Professional [[Actors' Equity Association|Equity]] [[Theatre]] Company located in [[Naples, Florida]]. It performs in the G&L Theatre on the Campus of [[The Community School of Naples]] at 13275 Livingston Road. TheatreZone is Collier County Florida's only resident Professional Equity Regional Theatre Company. The company concentrates on performing what it calls "The Lost Treasures Of Broadway", shows that are rarely performed and deserve to be seen.<ref>[http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/nov/08/tiffany_yates/ Tiffany Yates: My final bow to the future of theater in Southwest Florida : Showcase : Naples Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> <ref>[http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/nov/29/artists_join_forces_push_cultural_district_concept/ Artists join forces to push cultural district concept : Citizen : Naples Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/dec/13/curtain-theatrezone-gives-us-early-christmas-gift/ Curtain Up!: TheatreZone gives us early Christmas gift : Opinion : Naples Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=18431442&BRD=2605&PAG=461&dept_id=523946&rfi=6 Naples Sun Times - TheatreZone brings big talents to Naples<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==History== TheatreZone was founded in 2005 as not-for-profit 501(c)3 corporation. The company then obtained a Small Professional Theatres Contract with the [[Actors' Equity Association]].<ref>[http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/apr/21/theater_still_play_locally_naples_dinner_theatre_c/ Theater groups still in play from Naples to Estero : Local : Naples Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> <ref>[http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/jun/15/musical_revuu/ Musical revue celebrates songwriting hits of Burt Bacharach, Hal David : Local : Naples Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> TheatreZone's inaugural season opened with the musical [[Mack and Mabel]] on March 16, 2006. The production starred [[Gary Sandy]], most famous for his role on the 1970s and early 80's [[CBS]] [[Sitcom]] [[WKRP in Cincinnati]].<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.marconews.com/news/2006/mar/09/new_theatre_company_perform_mack_and_mable/ New theatre company to perform ‘Mack and Mable’ : citizen : Marco News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The show needed to be updated and TheatreZone was able to get in contact with composer [[Jerry Herman]] who allowed the rework of the show with his approval.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> Their second season included the play "Miracle in Rwanda," about a woman who survived the Rwandan genocide by hiding in a bathroom with seven other women for 91 days. The world premiere took place at TheatreZone on February 9, 2007. Following its premiere, the show moved to [[New York City]] for one month, and opened in [[Edinburgh, Scotland]] in August 2007.<ref>[http://www.miracleinrwanda.com/index.htm Miracle in Rwanda - Now Touring the World!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.edinburgh-festivals.com/reviews.cfm?id=1239792007 Edinburgh Festivals - Miracle in Rwanda<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.theatrezone-florida.com/ Theatre Zone]

{{notability|1=Biographies|date=May 2018}}
'''Tim Calkins''' (born July 27, 1965) is an [[author]], [[consultant]] and [[clinical professor]] of [[Marketing]] at [[Northwestern University]]’s [[Kellogg School of Management]] specializing in topics including [[Marketing Strategy]], Biomedical Marketing, and branding.<ref name=GoogleBooks>{{Cite web| title = Breakthrough Marketing Plans| author = | work = Google Books| date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02| url = https://books.google.com/books/about/Breakthrough_Marketing_Plans.html?id=FFLmDcWV21QC| language = | quote =}}</ref>
== Biography and Education == Tim Calkins was born in [[Buffalo, New York]] in 1965 to father Evan Calkins and mother Virginia Brady who were married on Sept. 9, 1946 and were both doctors. He has eight siblings, Sally, Stephen, Lucy, Joan, Benjamin, Hugh, Ellen, and Geoffrey.<ref name="livi_AGer">{{Cite web | title = A Geriatrician Enjoys Growing Older | author = | work = livingprimetime.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://livingprimetime.com/AllCovers/Nov1996/a_geriatrician_enjoys_growing_ol.htm | language = | quote = }}</ref><ref>Friendly, J. (1986, Aug 07). A SUMMER PLACE. New York Times</ref>
Calkins graduated from Hamburg High School, [[Hamburg, New York]] in 1983<ref name="news_Rick">{{Cite web| title = Rick Scholarship - Newspapers.com| author = | work = Newspapers.com| date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02| url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7823639/rick_scholarship/| quote = }}</ref> where he had been on the Honor Roll<ref>{{Cite web| title = Rick - Honor roll 1982 - Newspapers.com| author = | work = Newspapers.com| date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02| url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7823596/rick_honor_roll_1982/| quote = }}</ref> and he was awarded the Regents Scholarship<ref>{{Cite web| title = Rick Scholarship - 1983 - Newspapers.com| author = | work = Newspapers.com| date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02| url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/7823613/rick_scholarship_1983/| quote = }}</ref>. Subsequently, he received his [[Bachelor]]'s Degree from [[Yale University]] in 1987 and his [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1991.<ref name=vita>{{Cite web | title = Timothy Calkins - Faculty - Kellogg School of Management | author = | work = kellogg.northwestern.edu | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/faculty/directory/calkins_timothy.aspx#vita | language = | quote = }}</ref>
He currently lives in [[Chicago, Illinois]]<ref name="bloc_Timo">{{Cite web | title = Timothy Calkins and Carol A. Saltoun {{!}} 1253 West Oakdale Avenue, Chicago, IL 60657 | author = | work = blockshopper.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://blockshopper.com/il/cook-county/chicago/property/14291230020000/1253-west-oakdale-avenue | language = | quote = }}</ref> with his wife Carol Saltoun and his three children<ref name=HuffPostBio>{{Cite web | title = Tim Calkins {{!}} HuffPost | author = | work = huffingtonpost.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.huffingtonpost.com/author/tim-calkins | quote = }}</ref>.
== Career ==
Calkins began his career as a Research Associate at Booz Allen and Hamilton in [[New York, New York]] in 1987. From there he moved to the position of a Marketing [[Senior management|Executive]] at [[Kraft Foods]] in [[Glenview, Illinois]] from 1991 to 2002 where he managed leading brands including A.1. Steak Sauce, Kraft BBQ sauce, Miracle Whip and Taco Bell Home Originals.<ref name=GoogleBooks/>
In 1998, Calkins took a position of Professor of Marketing at the Kellogg School of Management as Adjunct Assistant Professor of Marketing. He was subsequently made Clinical Associate Professor of Marketing in 2002 and full Clinical Professor of Marketing in 2006. There he has earned several honors and awards including ''Executive MBA Program Outstanding Teaching Award'', ''Sidney J. Levy Teaching Award'', ''Faculty Impact Award'', and ''L. G. Lavengood Outstanding Professor of the Year Award''.<ref name=vita /> He was also chosen for Poets & Quants ''Our Favorite MBA Professors of 2016''.<ref name="poet_OurF">{{Cite web | title = Our Favorite MBA Professors Of 2016 - Page 2 of 3 | author = | work = Poets&Quants | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://poetsandquants.com/2017/01/04/favorite-business-school-professors-2016/2/ | quote = }}</ref>
He is the managing director of Class 5 Consulting<ref name=GoogleBooks/> where he provides consultation on projects and problems for clients including [[Eli Lilly]], [[Hewlett Packard]], [[Pfizer]], [[Teva Pharmaceutical Industries|Teva]], [[AB InBev]], [[Novartis]], and the [[American Dental Association]].<ref name="timc_Clas">{{Cite web | title = Class 5 - STRONGBRANDS | author = | work = STRONGBRANDS | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://timcalkins.com/speaking/ | quote = }}</ref>
== Works ==
Tim Calkins is the author of the books ''Breakthrough Marketing Plans'' (Palgrave Macmillan, 2008 and 2012) and ''Defending Your Brand: How Smart Companies Use Defensive Strategy to Deal with Competitive Attacks'' (Palgrave Macmillan, 2012). ''Defending Your Brand'' was the winner of the Expert Marketer Magazine’s Marketing Book of the Year in 2013.<ref name=BI>{{Cite web | title = Tim Calkins | author = | work = Business Insider | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://www.businessinsider.com/author/tim-calkins | quote = }}</ref><ref name="fipp_Expe">{{Cite web | title = Expert Marketer Magazine opens voting for Marketing Book of the Year 2014 | author = | work = fipp.com | date = 13 February 2014 | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.fipp.com/news/industrynews/expert-marketer-magazine-opens-voting-for-mar | language = | quote = }}</ref><ref name="mark_Mark">{{Cite web | title = Marketing Book of the Year 2013 - And the winner is... {{!}} Blog {{!}} MARKETING & SALES BOOKS | author = | work = marketingandsalesbooks.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://www.marketingandsalesbooks.com/en/news/1224/marketing-book-of-the-year-2013-and-the-winner-is | quote = }}</ref> He was also the co-editor of ''Kellogg on Branding'' (John Wiley & Sons, 2005).<ref name=BI />
Calkins is the founder of the Kellogg School Super Bowl Advertising Review which has reviewed [[Super Bowl]] advertisements since 2005.<ref name="kell_TheK">{{Cite web | title = The Kellogg Bowl: 2018 Super Bowl Ad Review | author = | work = kellogg.northwestern.edu | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/news-events/super-bowl.aspx | quote = }}</ref> He has also authored articles on the importance of Super Bowl advertising from the point of view of Marketing.<ref name=HuffPostBio /><ref>{{Cite web | title = Tim Calkins {{!}} HuffPost | author = | work = huffingtonpost.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.huffingtonpost.com/author/tim-calkins | quote = }}</ref>
He has published more than a dozen Kellogg case studies including Crestor, MedImmune: FluMist Introduction and Genzyme: the Synvisc-One Investment Decision as well as articles in industry journals.<ref name=BI /><ref name="kell_Timo">{{Cite web | title = Timothy Calkins - Faculty - Kellogg School of Management | author = | work = kellogg.northwestern.edu | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = http://www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/faculty/directory/calkins_timothy.aspx#research | language = | quote = }}</ref> He is also contributor and author for many marketing and news outlets including Business Insider<ref name=BI />, [[Huffington Post]] <ref name=HuffPostBio />, [[Financial Times]]<ref name="ft.c_Itis">{{Cite web | title = It is time to rethink business school case studies for millennials | author = | work = Financial Times | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.ft.com/content/93eb740a-422c-11e7-82b6-896b95f30f58 | quote = }}</ref>, and [[The New York Times]] <ref name="nyti_Bran">{{Cite web | title = Brands Start Planning for Unexpected Criticism by Trump | last = Schonbrun | first = Zach | work = nytimes.com | date = 25 December 2016 | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/25/business/media/advertising-brands-criticism-by-trump.html | quote = }}</ref>. His blog, Strong Brands, was featured on Inc.com as one of ''Six Blogs That Can Teach You More Than an MBA''.<ref name="inc._6Blo">{{Cite web | title = 6 Blogs That Can Teach You More Than an MBA | author = | work = Inc.com | date = | accessdate = 2018-03-02 | url = https://www.inc.com/jeremy-goldman/6-blogs-that-can-teach-you-more-than-an-mba.html | quote = }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External Links ==
[http://timcalkins.com Strong Brands - Tim Calkins' Blog]

page.title: University of Santo Tomas College of Architecture

revision.text:
{{Infobox college | name = [[University of Santo Tomas]]
College of Architecture | image = {{nowrap|[[File:UST College of Architecture.png|x100px]] [[File:UST-CollegeOfArchitecture.png|x100px]]}} | established = 1930 | former_names = * 1930 – Department of Architecture (Faculty of Engineering) * 1938 – School of Architecture and Fine Arts * 1946 – College of Architecture and Fine Arts * 2000 – College of Architecture | dean = Arch. Rodolfo P. Ventura | head_label = Regent | head = Rev. Fr. Manuel F. Roux, OP, SThL-MA | students = 2,159 (as of 2011){{cite web |url=http://www.varsitarian.net/special_reports/20110126/too_many_students_so_few_classrooms |title=Too many students, so few classrooms |author1=Bulauan, J.A.A. |author2=Garcia, J.C.V. |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[The Varsitarian]] |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-06-06}} | location = Beato Angelico Building, Tamayo Drive, [[University of Santo Tomas|UST]], [[Sampaloc, Manila]] | colors = {{color box|#7f242b}} Maroon | free_label = [[Traditions of University of Santo Tomas#Insignias|Patron saint]] | free = [[Thomas the Apostle]] | website = }} The '''University of Santo Tomas College of Architecture''' is the architectural school of the [[University of Santo Tomas]], the oldest and the largest [[Catholic]] university in [[Manila]], [[Philippines]]. Established in 1930, the college is one of the first architectural schools in the [[Philippines]]. It is also one of the only 2 to be proclaimed as a '''Center of Excellence''' in ''[[Architecture]]'' by the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Commission on Higher Education]] and a consistent Top Performing Architecture School in the Philippine Architecture Licensure Examination. ==Brief history== Established in 1930, it is one of the ''first architectural schools'' in the [[Philippines]]. It was renamed ''College of Architecture and Fine Arts'' in 1946 following the integration of Fine Arts degrees. The college was split in 2000, thus forming the [[University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design|College of Fine Arts and Design]], separating the College of Architecture. The college was housed in the Roque Ruaño building which it shared with the [[University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Engineering|Faculty of Engineering]]. It later moved in the new Beato Angelico building, together with the [[University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design|College of Fine Arts and Design]]. ==Degree Program== *'''Bachelor of Science in Architecture'''- The 5-year program consists of 10 consecutive semesters of design subjects that focus on fundamental design knowledge where students design buildings from simple residential projects to complex multi-family dwelling structures, multi-storey buildings of residential or commercial complexes, institutional buildings like schools, civic centers, religious structures, health facilities, etc. Urban planning and design, environmental concern, building technology, and professional practice are among other subjects.http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=361&Itemid=85 At the end of their third year, students will choose their specialization track from the three that are currently offered by the college, namely, Heritage Conservation, Environmental Management Planning, and Landscape Architecture. ==Administration== *'''Dean''' - Arch. Rodolfo P. Ventura, UAP, [[Master of Science|MS]] (Architecture) *'''Regent''' - Rev. Fr. Manuel F. Roux, OP, SThL-MA *'''Asst. Dean''' - Arch./Atty. Marlon M. Carino, UAP *'''Secretary''' - Arch. Charice U. Ong, UAP, [[Master of Science|MS]] (Architecture) ==Notable alumni== The College has produced numerous men and women of the arts that gradually helped shaped Philippine Arts and Architecture. *[[Aida-Cruz Del Rosario]] - The first female graduate of the college (1946), and the first female architect in the [[Philippines]].Thomasian Sunscope The official alumni newsletter of the University of Santo Tomas March 2008 issue{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/fashion-and-beauty/2012-07-18/828789/full-life-90|title=Full of life at 90|work=philstar.com}} While some sources credit [[Eulie Chowdhury]] as the first woman architect in Asia,{{Cite web|url=https://undiaunaarquitecta.wordpress.com/2015/06/08/urmila-eulie-chowdhury-1923/|title=Urmila Eulie Chowdhury 1923–1995|accessdate=15 October 2015|date=8 June 2015|language=Spanish|publisher= Un Día / Una Arquitecta}}{{cite book|title=International Archive of Women in Architecture Newsletter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3NpOAAAAYAAJ|year=1989|publisher=International Archive of Women in Architecture, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University}} others including Aida-Cruz Del Rosario were working at similar dates,{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/fashion-and-beauty/2012-07-18/828789/full-life-90|title=Full of life at 90|work=philstar.com}} and women like [[Perin Jamsetjee Mistri]] and [[Dora Gad]] preceded them. *Ang Kiukok - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Visual Arts]] *Ildefonso Santos Jr - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Architecture]] *[[Juan Nakpil]] - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Architecture]] *J. Elizalde Navarro - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Visual Arts]] *Leandro Locsin - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Architecture]] *[[Francisco Mañosa]] - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Architecture]] and the designer of the [[Coconut Palace]]. *Victorio Edades - [[National Artists of the Philippines|National Artists]] for [[Visual Arts]] *Jose Pedro "Bong" Recio - ''Founder'' '''Recio+Casas''' Architectural firm. Designed [[The Shang Grand Tower]], [[G.T. International Tower]], [[LKG Tower]], [[Pacific Plaza Towers]] in Fort Bonifacio, the [[University of Santo Tomas Sports Complex|UST Sports Complex]], UST Multi-deck Carpark, etc.http://www.emporis.com/en/cd/cm/?id=109888 *Carmelo Casas - ''Founder'' '''Recio+Casas''' Architectural firm. Designed [[The Shang Grand Tower]], [[G.T. International Tower]], [[LKG Tower]], [[Pacific Plaza Towers]] in Fort Bonifacio, the [[University of Santo Tomas Sports Complex|UST Sports Complex]], UST Multi-deck Carpark, etc. *[[Felino Palafox]] - ''Founder'' '''Palafox Associates''', ranked 94th (2006), is the ''only Southeast Asian Architectural firm'' to be included in the '''BD World Architecture'''. Designed the Rockwell Center in Makati, La Mesa Watershed, Ortigas Center, Makati Streetscape, Hidalgo Place, Jeddah Riviera Center, [[Saudi Arabia]], Jumeirah Beach Residences, Dubai, Rabat Waterfront Development, [[Morocco]], Rizal Tower, etc.http://www.palafoxoutsourcing.com/main/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1 * Gabriel Formoso,founder of GF&P (Gabriel Formoso and Partners) the designer of a number of notable structures such as the Asian Institute of Management, Manila Peninsula Hotel, PBCom Tower, Pacific Star building among others. * Engracio Mariano * Abelardo Tolentino ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ust.edu.ph/ University of Santo Tomas] - Official Website {{UST}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Santo Tomas Architecture, University Of}} [[Category:University of Santo Tomas|Architecture]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1930]] [[Category:Architecture schools]]

{{Underlinked|date=October 2017}}
'''XML Certification Program (XML Master)''' is an IT [[professional certification]] for [[XML]] and related technologies. There are two levels of XML Certifications, '''XML Master Basic''' certification and '''XML Master Professional''' certification, and more than 18,000 people have passed the examinations.
==Certification paths==
===XML Master Professional Application Developer Certification=== *XML Master Professional Application Developer is a certificate for professionals who have demonstrated the ability to use technology in developing applications that deal with XML data. It is based on passing the Master Basic exam and the XML Master Professional Application Developer exam.
====XML Master Professional Application Developer Certification Exam==== *Duration => 90 minutes *Number of Questions => 45 *Required Passing Score => 70%
=====Exam Topics===== *Section 1 - DOM / SAX *Section 2 - DOM / SAX Programming *Section 3 - XSLT *Section 4 - XML Schema *Section 5 - XML Processing System Design Technology *Section 6 - Utilizing XML
===XML Master Professional Database Administrator Certification=== *The XML Master Professional Database Administrator is a certificate for professionals who have demonstrated the ability to use technology in XQuery and XMLDB. It requires passing the XML Master Basic exam and the XML Master Professional Database Administrator exam.
====XML Master Professional Database Administrator Certification Exam==== *Duration in minutes => 90 minutes *Number of Questions => 30 *Required Passing Score => 80%
=====Exam Topics===== *Section 1 - Overview *Section 2 - XQuery, XPath *Section 3 - Manipulating XML Data *Section 4 - Creating XML Schema and Other XML Database Objects
===XML Master Basic Certification=== *XML Master Basic is a certification for professionals who have demonstrated the ability to use XML and related technologies, based on passing the XML Master Basic certification exam.
====XML Master Basic Certification Exam==== *Duration in minutes => 90 minutes *Number of Questions => 50 *Minimum Passing Score => 70%
=====Exam Topics===== *Section 1 - XML Overview *Section 2 - Creating XML Documents *Section 3 - DTD *Section 4 - XML Schema *Section 5 - XSLT, XPath *Section 6 - Namespace
==External links==
===XML Certification Program (XML Master) official website===
*[http://www.xmlmaster.org/en Introduction to XML Certification Program: XML Master] *[http://www.xmlmaster.org/en/practice_exam/ XML Master Certification Practice Exam] *[http://www.xmlmaster.org/en/success/index.html XML Master Certification Success Stories]
[[Category:XML]] [[Category:Information technology qualifications]]
